editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.p: A CURE FOR THE HEART-ACHE, A COMEDY, IN FIVE ACTS, AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL, COVENT-GARDEN
By THOMAS MORTON, Eſq. AUTHOR OF COLUMBUS, ZORINSKI, WAY TO GET MARRIED, AND CHILDREN IN THE WOOD.
DUBLIN: Printed by P. WOGAN, Old Bridge. 1797.

div.head: PROLOGUE,
div.byline: WRITTEN BY T. W. FITZGERALD, Eſq. Spoken by Mr. Macready.

sp.l: WHEN invalids poſſeſs both faith and wealth,
They'll find a noſtrum to reſtore their health;
A panacea advertis'd to cure
Each ill the human body can endure.
But our bold Author claims a nobler art,
And advertiſes to relieve—the heart.
So many patients he expects to ſee,
That I'm appointed as his deputy.
Now, then, your mental maladies explain,
And I'll remove or mitigate the pain.
Does love or jealouſy your peace moleſt,
Revenge inflame, ambition gnaw your breaſt?
For jealouſy, a ſovereign balm behold,—
The huſband's certain cure, a pill of gold;
This doſe, adminiſter'd with prudent care,
Diſpels at once the frailties of the fair;
Deprives the proctor of his crim. con. fee,
And tunes the chord that jar'd to harmony.
Should love torment ſome Romeo's heated brain,
Or agonize a Juliet's breaſt with pain,
Let them my potent remedy apply,—
The maid ſhall ceaſe to pine, the youth to ſigh;
Gold ſhall reſtore each drooping lover's health,
And paſſion ſind a ſubſtitute in wealth.
But let not ill-tim'd ridicule degrade
What Heav'n, when well applied, a bleſſing made.
To foſter merit, whereſoever found,
And with improvement cheer a country round;
To feed the hungry, and to clothe the poor,
And ſend the beggar happy from the door;
To mitigate the horrors of deſpair,
And make the family of want our care;
To ſuccour genius, drooping in diſtreſs,
Making the buſineſs of our lives to bleſs.
When the rich man can ſuch employment find,
We wiſh his purſe as ample as his mind.
For one poor patient I've an anxious fear;
And you muſt be his kind phyſician here.
Our Author has to night ſo much at ſtake,
He finds his throbbing heart inclin'd to ache!
But ſhould his play a lib'ral audience pleaſe,
Your warm applauſe will ſet his heart at eaſe.

div.head: DRAMATIS PERSONAE.
A CURE FOR THE HEART-ACHE, A COMEDY.
ACT I.
SCENE I. A Farm Yard. Houſe on one Side, a neat Flower-Garden on the other. The Bells of a Team jingling.

sp.speaker: FRANK
sp.p: WOYH! Whoh! Smiler! (Enters.) So Feyther be not come home from the Nabob's houſe yet. Eh! bean't that ſiſter Jeſſy, in her garden, buſy among the poſeys?—Siſter Jeſſy!

div.stage: Enter JESSY from the Garden, a watering-pot in her hand.

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Ah, Frank! ſo ſoon returned from Glouceſter? have you ſold the corn?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ees.

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: And how did you like the town? you were never there before?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Loike it! I don't know how I loiked it, not I; L zomehow cou'dn't zee the town for the houſen: deſperate zight of 'em, to be ſure.—But Jeſſy, you who went to Lunnun Town to take in your larning, can tell me, be there as many houſes in Lunnun?

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: A hundred times the number.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And do your 'ſquires there, like Sir Hubert Stanley, and the Nabob here, keep fine coaches?

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Yes, Frank; there are ſome thouſands round St. James's Gate.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: St. James's Geat! Dong it; it wou'd be worth a poor man's while to ſtand and open that geat.—Pray you, where do that geat lead to?

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: The road to preferment, Frank.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ecod, if your road to preferment be ſo cramm'd wi' your coaches and great folk, no wonder a poor man be run down when he tries to get a bit.

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You ſeem to be in terrible good ſpirits, Jeſſy.

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: I have reaſon, Frank. I have juſt received a letter from my dear Edward, who has left London on buſineſs with his father, Mr. Rapid, and will be here to day.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe it to be a deſperate long letter, and cruel ſweet. Full of kiſſes and voluntines.— Nine ſheets, I warrant.

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Hardly nine words. The truth is, that Edward, tho' handſome, generous, and I hope ſince •• is impatient and haſty to a degree that—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p:
Haſty! What then? when a man be on the road to do good, he can't go too faſt, I ſay.— Bean't that Feyther coming thro' Wheat Aſh? he have been drinking and gameſtring all good Sunday night wi' Nabob's ſervants,—how whitiſh and deadly bad he do look. He us'd to be as comely and handſome as either of us, wasn't he now? Do you know, Jeſſy, at church yeſterday, Sir Hubert, looking round, as he always do to ſee if his tenants be there, miſſed Feyther, and gave me ſuch a deſperate look, that I dropt prayer book out of my hand; and truly when Feyther do go to church I be always ſham'd he never knows where to fin the collect—never—I'm ſure it be not my fault, he be ſo full of prodigality—
never ſon ſet Feyther better example than I do's mine; what can I do more for 'un? it would not be becoming in me to leather Feather, would it, Jeſſy.

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Here he comes, I'll return to my garden— to converſe with him is to me dreadful; for, while my breaſt riſes with indignation at his conduct as a man, it ſinks again in pity for the misfortunes of a parent.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Now that's juſt like I—I feels as if I ſhould like to lick 'un, and cry all the time—But what will be the end on't, Jeſſy?

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Ruin, inevitable ruin!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Well don't thee be caſt down—thee knows I be cruel kind to thee; at meals I always gis thee the deſperate nice bits, and if thy lover prove falſe hearted, or Feyther ſhould come to decay, I be a terrible ſtrong lad, I'll work for thee fra ſunriſe to down, and if any one offer to harm thee, I'll fight for thee till I die.

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Thanks, my good lad! thanks, dear brother.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: As nice a bit of a ſiſter that, as in all country round.

div.stage: Enter FARMER OATLAND (dreſſed in a compound of ruſticity and faſhion.

sp.speaker: Oatld.
sp.p: Ba viamo tutti tra.—Dom it, this be what I call loife! Have you ſold the wheat?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ees.

sp.speaker: Oatld.
sp.p: How much?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Two load—Six and twenty pound.

sp.speaker: Oatld.
sp.p: Exactly the trifle I loſt laſt night.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Oatld.
sp.p: Take it to the Nabob's gentleman.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I were going Feyther, to the caſtle, to ge it to Sir Hubart's ſteward for rent.

sp.speaker: Oatld.
sp.p: Rent, you bore! That for Sir Hubert. (ſnapping his fingers). Ah, Nabob's ſervants be the tippy.—Every thing be done by them ſo genteelly.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ecod you be done by them genteelly enough; I be ſure that houſe have brought the country round to ruination. Before this Nabob came here wi' all his money and be domn'd to 'un, every thing were as peaceable and deceant as never was;— not a lawyer within ten miles; now there be three practiſing in village; and what's ameaſt as bad, there be three doctors; and the farmers ſo conſated, drive about in their chay carts, eat lump ſugar ev'ry day, and gi'balls.

sp.speaker: Oatld.
sp.p: To be ſure.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And what's the upſhot? why that they jig it away to country jail.

sp.speaker: Oatld.
sp.p: Tezez vous! Let me ſee—Great caſſino be ten o diamonds. Well then, I play—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Play! ecod, if you go on ſo, you mun work tho'.

sp.speaker: Oatld.
sp.p: Next, I muſt take care of the ſpeads.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: No, Feyther, a ſpade mun take care o' you; By gol, here be Mr. Heartly, Sir Hubert's ſteward, now don't you be ſaucy to un, Feyther;— now do behave thyzelf—now that's a man, Feyther, do.

sp.speaker: Heartly.
sp.p: Good day, Farmer Oatland; how doſt do, honeſt Frank?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Deſperate pure, thank ye, ſur.

sp.speaker: Heartly.
sp.p: Well, farmer, once more I have called reſpecting your arrear of rent—Three hundred pound is a long ſum.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Three hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Heartly.
sp.p: And unleſs it be immediately diſcharged, Sir Hubert is reſolved to—

sp.speaker: Oatld.
sp.p: That for Sir Hubert—He ſhall have his rent—Frank, ſend your ſiſter Jeſſy to the Nabob's, he'll let me have the money.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: No! I won't—What buſineſs have ſiſter at ſuch a deſperate prodigal place. Na, na, I'll go myzelf.

sp.speaker: Heartly.
sp.p: You are in the right, honeſt Frank.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Yes, ſur, I always am.

sp.speaker: Oatld.
sp.p: Ugh! you vulgar mongrel—Well, deſire the Nabob's gentleman to deſire the Nabob to let me have three hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: He won't gi' thee a braſs farthing.

sp.speaker: Oatld.
sp.p: Sir Hubert ſhall have his money— Ha! ha! ha! my notion is, he wants it ſad enough, ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Heartly.
sp.p: Sirrah!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Don't you mind 'un, ſur, don't ye, he be's intoſticated. Dong thee behave thyſelf.

sp.speaker: Oatld.
sp.p: Silence, you hound! and obey!—Bon jour, Mr. Steward,—I'll to bed—'Pon honor, I muſt cut champagne, it makes me ſo narvous —Sir Hubert ſhall have his money, let that ſatisfy,—Follow me, cur.

sp.speaker: Heartly.
sp.p: Sad doings, Frank.

div.stage: (FRANK ſhakes his head and follows OATLAND

div.head: SCENE II—A Room in the Nabob's houſe

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Good Mr. Bronze, have you been at Sir Hubert Stanley's?

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Is Charles Stanley arrived?

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: No, ma'am; but he is hourly expected.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Do they ſay he is well—quite recovered?

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p:
I don't know, ma'am—upon my ſoul—I beg pardon, but really the Baronet's houſe is horrid vulgar, compared to your uncle's, the Nabob's here; I peeped thro' my glaſs into an old hall, and beheld fifty paupers at dinner, ſuch wretches! and the Baronet himſelf walking round the table to ſee them properly fed.—How damn'd low!—Ugh! I would bett a rump and dozen our ſecond table is more genteelerer than Sir Hubert's own—but I muſt away, for we expect the rich Miſs Vortex—I beg pardon; but your name and the Nabob's
daughter being the ſame, we call her the rich, to diſtinguiſh—

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: And you do wiſely—no term of diſtinction cou'd poſſibly be more ſignificant or better underſtood by the world, than that you have adopted.

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: Hope no offence, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: None, Bronze, go in.—

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: The laſt man on earth to offend a fine woman.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: The rich Miſs Vortex—moſt true.—But now my dear Charles Stanley is return'd, I claim the ſuperior title of the Happy. Oh! Charles, when we parted laſt at Spa; how great the contraſt; thy animated form was priſon'd in the icy fetters of diſeaſe; thy pale and quiv'ring lip refuſed a laſt adieu;—But ah! a ſmile that ſeemed borrowed from a ſeraph who waited to bear thee up to Heaven, ſwore for thee everlaſting love. That ſmile ſupported me in ſolitude,—but to ſolitude I have now bade adieu, and to be near the lord of my heart, have again enter'd this houſe, the palace of ruinous luxury and licentious madneſs; but here comes its whimſical proprietor.

div.stage: Enter Mr. VORTEX with a paper in his hand, attended by black and white ſervants.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Sublime!—oh, the fame of this ſpeech will ſpread to Indoſtan. Eh!—don't I ſmell the pure air in this room? Oh! you villains! would you deſtroy me, throw about the perfumes for legiſlative profundity; for fancy and decoration,—'tis a ſpeech.—

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: What ſpeech is it, Sir?

sp.speaker: Vortex
sp.p: Ah! Ellen—why my maiden ſpeech in Parliament—it will alarm all Europe—I'll ſpeak it to you.—

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: No, my dear uncle, not juſt now—I hear you've been ill.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Oh! very—a ſtrange agitation at my heart, and ſuch a whizzing and ſpinning in my head—

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: I hope you've had advice?—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Oh, yes, I've had them all.—One phyſician told me it was cauſed by too brilliant and efferveſcent a genius;—the next ſaid, it was the ſcurvy; —a third, it proceeded from not eating pepper to a melon;—another had the impudence to hint it was only little qualms that agitated ſome gentlemen who had made fortunes in India;—one recommended a ſea voyage,—another a flannel night-cap;—one preſcrib'd water,—the other brandy; but, however they all agreed in this eſſential point, that I'm not to be contradicted, but have my way in every thing.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: An extremely pleaſant preſcription, certainly. But under theſe circumſtances do you hold it prudent, uncle, to become a parliamentary Orator? I believe a little gentle contradiction is uſual in that Houſe.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: I know it—but if you will hear my ſpeech, you will ſee how I manage—I begin —Sir—

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Your daughter, ſir, is arrived from Town.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Thank you couſin for this relief.—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Zounds! I'm not to be interrupted.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: She is here, ſir.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: My dear Nabob, uncommon glad to ſee you. Ah! Ellen; what, tired of ſecluſion and a cottage?

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: I hope, couſin, I am welcome to you.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Certainly; you know we are uncommon glad to ſee any body in the country—but, my dear Nabob, you don't inquire about the opening of our town-houſe.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: I was thinking of my ſpeech.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: The moſt brilliant houſe-warming— uncommon full, above a thouſand people—every body there.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Pray, couſin, do you then viſit every body?

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Certainly, they muſt aſk me.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Muſt! I ſhou'd imagine that wou'd depend on inclination.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Inclination! pſha! I beg your pardon; but you are really uncommon ignorant my dear. They muſt aſk me, I tell you.—Now ſuppoſe a Dutcheſs raſh enough to ſhut me from her parties; —very well.—She names a night.—I name the ſame, and give an entertainment greatly ſurpaſſing her's in ſplendour and profuſion.—What is the conſequence? —why, that her rooms are as deſerted as an Ex-miniſter's levee, and mine cramm'd to ſuffocation with her Grace's moſt puiſſant and noble friends.—Ha! ha! my dear Ellen, the court of St. James's run after a good ſupper as eagerly as the court of Aldermen.—Ha! ha! your being in this country, Nabob, was thought quite charming.—A hoſt not being at home to receive his gueſts is uncommon new and elegant, isn't.—Here we improve, my dear, on ancient hoſpitality—thoſe little memorandums, Nabob, will give you an idea of the ſort of thing.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: "March."—Oh! that's a delightful month, when Nature produces nothing, and every thing is forc'd.—Let me ſee—" 50 quarts of green peas at five guineas a quart,"—that was pretty well:—"500 peaches"—at what?—" a guinea each."—Oh! too cheap.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: 'Tis very true; but I aſſure you I tried every where to get them dearer, but cou'd not.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: And I ſuppoſe the new white ſattin furniture was all ſpoil'd.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Oh! entirely—and the pier glaſſes ſhivered to pieces ſo delightfully.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Well, I hope you had the whole account put in the papers?

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Certainly, elſe what would have been the uſe of giving the fete. Then the company; ſuch charming eccentricity, ſuch characters out of character.—We had a noble Peer bowing for cuſtom to his ſhop, and an Alderman turning over the muſic leaves for the celebrated Soprano; an Orator's lady detailing her hnſband's three hours ſpeech in Parliament, and the Orator himſelf deſcribing how puppets are managed at the Fantoccini; we had grandmothers making aſſignations with boys, and the children of Iſrael joining the hoſt of Pharaoh.—Oh! my dear Miſs Vortex, why don't you partake in theſe charming ſcenes?

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: My dear Miſs Vortex, ſix ſuppers would annihilate my fortune.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Oh true, I forgot your uncommon ſmall fortune. But I don't think it much ſignifies. I ſwear, people of faſhion in town ſeem to do as well without money, as with it. You might be ſucceſsful at play. There are points to be learnt, which certainly do not give you the worſt of the game. Come, will you be my protegée?

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Excuſe me, couſſn, I dare ſay I ought to be covered with bluſhes, when I own a vulgar deteſtation of the character of a female gameſter, and I muſt decline the honor of your introduction to the haut ton till at leaſt they have juſtice on their ſide.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: An uncommon odd girl, Nabob.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Heavens! to what ſtate of abject degradation muſt faſhionable ſociety be reduced, when officers of police are as much dreaded by ladies in the purlieus of St. James's, as they are by cut purſes in the wretched haunts of St. Giles.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: For ſhame, Ellen, to cenſure your own ſex.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: No, madam, I am its advocate, and in that ſex's name proteſt an abhorrence of thoſe women, who do not conſider any thing ſhameful but to be aſhamed of any thing; whoſe reſemblance to nature and innocence exiſts but in their nakedneſs, and to whom honour is only known as a pledge at a gaming table.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Did you ever hear, Nabob?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: I did not hear a word ſhe ſaid; I was thinking of my ſpeech.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: A pert, Gothic, low-bred creature! But her contemptible fortune ſuits uncommon well with her grovelling ideas.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Don't talk of her fortune, it always makes my poor head worſe. You know at the time I gave her five thouſand pounds in lieu of what I called her expectations, I had in my hands an enormous ſum of her's. O dear! I'm afraid the doctor was right—ah! mine are certainly Eaſt India qualms—I wonder if giving her fifty thouſand back again wou'd do my heart any good.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: What! my dear Nabob? I declare you quite ſhock me.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Oh conſcience!

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Conſcience! he! he! a thing ſo uncommon vulgar, a thing ſo completely chauſſeed; beſides, yon know very well it is abſolutely impoſſible to exiſt under 20,000l. a-year.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: That's very true.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Some people certainly do contrive to grub on with ten thouſand, but how they do it is to me miraculous; then think of your intention of marrying me to the ſon of your great rival the baronet; think of his borough.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Ah! very true.—Conſcience avaunt; I have made a motion on matrimony to Sir Hubert.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: And young Stanley's arrival; Oh! what a ſweet youth!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Oh! what a ſweet borough intereſt! But I am glad your heart is intereſted.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Heart intereſted! Lud, how can you ſuſpect me of ſo uncommon vulgar a ſenſation. I truſt my joy is occaſioned by ideas more becoming a woman of faſhion.—I am charm'd becauſe his fortune is large, his family ancient; and becauſe my marriage will render all my female friends ſo uncommon miſerable; and becauſe I ſuſpect that Ellen met young Stanley at Spa, and that ſhe dares aſpire to—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: I wiſh ſhe were out of the houſe.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: No—ſhe ſhall ſtay to witneſs my triumph.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Shall ſtay.—I'm not to be contradicted, you know—my phyſicians—

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Certainly not, my dear Nabob; but I may recommend; I'm ſure no phyſician would object to your taking advice. Ah! does Ellen love you as I do?—will ſhe liſten to your ſpeech as I intend to do?—would ſhe throw away thouſands for you in a night, as I do?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Very true! very true!

div.head: SCENE III.—A Pleaſure Ground, and View of an ancient Caſtle.
div.stage: Enter four Servants dreſs'd in old faſhion'd liveries, then Sir HUBERT STANLEY and HEARTLY.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Good Heartly, is all prepar'd for my boy's reception, his favourite ſtudy on the ſouthern battlement?—Are his dogs train'd—his hunters well condition'd?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: To ſay truth, Sir Hubert, the caſtle has been all day in quarrel, each ſervant claiming the right of excluſive attendance on his dear young maſter.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: I thank their honeſt loves. He writes me he is well, good Heartly; quite well.—Ha! the village bells proclaim my boy's arrival.—Doſt thou hear the people's ſhouts?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Aye, and it revives my old heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Theſe welcomes are the genuine effuſions of love and gratitude.—Spite of this Nabob's arts, you ſee how my loving neighbours reſpect me.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Not yet arriv'd, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Theſe rejoicings are for the Nabob's daughter, who is juſt come from London.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Indeed! (pecviſhly) Well, well.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: My young maſter will alight privately at Oatland farm, and walk through the park.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: The Nabob's daughter?—Well, let it paſs.—Heartley, what ſaid farmer Oatland?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Nothing but what profligacy and inſolence dictated—he deſied your power, and ſent to the Nabob.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Ungrateful man! let a diſtreſ be iſſued. —Hold; no, no.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir Hubert, he is undeſerving your lenity.—Beſides, ſir, your mortgagee, Mr. Rapid, the wealthy taylor, will be here to-day— the intereſt on the mortgage muſt be paid—ſome of your election bills remain unliquidated, and I fear without a ſurther mortgage—

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Don't torture. Pardon me, good old man.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Truly, Sir Hubert, what might have been effected with 5000l, ſome years ago, will now require ten—you muſt retrench your hoſpitable benevolence.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: My worthy ſteward, my head has long acknowledg'd the truth of your arithmetic—but my head could never teach it to my heart.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: And, ſir, you may raiſe your rents.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Never, Heartley.—never.—What! ſhall the many ſuffer that I may be at eaſe!—But away with care—this is a moment devoted to extaſy —this is the hour a doating father is to claſp an only child, who, after combating with diſeaſe and death, returns triumphant to his arms in luſty health and manhood.—Ah! he approaches; 'tis my boy—Doſt thou not ſee him in the beechen avenue. —Dull old man, advance thine hand thus,— (putting his hand over his forehead)—See how his eyes wander with delight, and renovate the pictures of his youth.—Ah! now he ſees his father, and ſties like lightning.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: My honour'd—my lov'd father!

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p:
Riſe to my heart.—Stand off, and let my eyes gloat upon thee—thou art well—Thy arm,
good Heartley.—Nay, do not weep, old Honeſty, 'twill infect me.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Ah! my excellent old friend—in health I hope?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Aye, good maſter, and this day will make me young again.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Dear father, already muſt I become a ſuitor to you.—Paſſing Oatland farm, I found his lovely daughter Jeſſy in tears, occaſion'd by her father's inability to pay his rent. I dried them with a promiſe— (Heartley ſhakes his head, and Sir Hubert averts his face).—Ha! your brow is clouded with unhappineſs;—pray, ſir—

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Good Heartley, leave us— (Exeunt HEARTLEY and Servants.)—Charles, ſo mix'd is the cup of life, that this day, the happieſt thy old father can e'er hope to ſee, is daſh'd with bitterneſs and ſorrow, boy. I've been a very unthrift to thee.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Oh, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Liſten to me.—You have heard how my father kept alive the benevolent hoſpitality that once diſtinguiſh'd old England, and I not finding in modern ethics aught likely to improve either the morals or happineſs of mankind, determin'd to perſevere in the ways of my fathers. Soon after you went abroad the adjoining eſtate was purchaſed by an Eaſt Indian, groaning under wealth produc'd by groans. Like the viper, after collecting in the warm ſunſhine his bag of venom, he came to the abode of peace and innocence, and diſſeminated his poiſon. But mark me—think me not ſo unjuſt, boy, as with random ſlander to cenſure any body of men. No, thank heaven; there are numbers whom Providence, in addition to the power, has added the will, to render wealth a bleſſing to all around them.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: You are ever juſt and liberal.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p:
But for this vile exception, this Mr. Vortex, I tell thee, riot, contention, indolence, and vice ſucceeded. I ſtruggled againſt this miſchieſ, which ſpurr'd him on to oppoſe me in my election. This conteſt (I truſt, Charlea, you think
the dignity of your family demanded it)—this conteſt, I ſay, obliged me to mortgage my eſtate to a conſiderable amount; and I fear, boy, even that will not ſuffice.—Doſt thou not blame thy father?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Blame, ſir? my fortune, nay, my life is held but to promote your happineſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Glorious boy! then all will be well again—thy eſtate reſtor'd, thy wealth enlarg'd

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: By marriage, Charles.—

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Marriage, ſir!—To conceal the paſſion that triumphs here were but to deceive a father, and injure the bright excellence I love. When I was ill at Spa, the votaries of pleaſure avoided me as the harbinger of melancholy, and I was deſpis'd as a thing paſſing into oblivion by all but one fair creature. I obtain'd an opportunity to thank her for the charitable pity her eye had beam'd on me. Love ſoon kindled his torch at Pity's altar, for I found in Miſs Vortex ſuch excellence—

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Miſs Vortex, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: From India?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: The ſame.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: She that is now propos'd for your alliance.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Is it poſſible?

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: And waits your arrival in the neighbourhood.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Oh! let me haſte to her.—Yet hold! Frank Oatland attends to hear your determination.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: At preſent, Charles, I cannot grant your ſuit.— (CHARLES beckons in FRANK)—Young man, tell your father the law muſt take its courſe. When I ſee in him ſymptoms of contrition and amendmert, I may reſtore him.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Thank ye,—thank ye, ſur.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: How came this diſtreſs to fall on him?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p:
Why, ſur, he went on farmering pretty tightiſh, didn't he, ſur? till he keep't company wi' Nabob's ſarvants; then all of a ſudden, he took to the gentlemen line. I conceats, ſur, he did'nt
much underſtand the trim on't, for the gentleman line didn't anſwer at all. I hope your honour bean't angry wi' I for ſpeaking to young 'Squire; your worſhip do know I were a bit of a playfellow wi' un, and we followed our ſtudies together.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ect, ſur, we went through our letters— and a-b, ab—c-b, eb—there ſomehow I ſtuck, and 'Squire went clean away into abreviation and abcmination; and then I never cou'd take much to your pens, they be ſo cruel ſmall; now a pitchfork do fit my hand ſo deſperate kindly as never was.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Ha! ha! Come my boy, you'll want refreſhment.

div.stage: Exit. FRANK bows, and is going.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: What honeſt Frank, will you not walk with me to the caſtle?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: If your honour be ſo gracious.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Nay, wear your hat.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: O dear! O dear! what a pity nobody do ſee I.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Come, brother ſtudent, your hand.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: My hand! Lord dong it, only think o'I.

div.head: ACT II.
SCENE I. A Room in an Inn.
div.stage: Enter two Waiters with Luggage, meeting Bronze.

sp.speaker: Iſt Wait.
sp.p: Coming Sir.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Zounds why don't you come? why don't all of you come, eh!

sp.speaker: Brenze.
sp.p: Waiter, who are theſe people?

sp.speaker: Iſt. Wait.
sp.p: I don't know, Mr. Bronze.—The young one ſeems a queer one—he jump'd out of the mail, ran into the kitchen, whipp'd the turnſpit into a gallop, and bade him keep moving; and tho' not a minute in the houſe, he had been in every room, from the garret to the cellar.

sp.speaker: 2d. Wait.
sp.p: Father and ſon I underſtand.—The name on the luggage, I ſee, is Rapid.

sp.speaker: Bronza.
sp.p: Rapid! (aſide). Perhaps it is my old maſter, the great taylor, and his harum-ſcarum ſon —I'll obſerve.

sp.speaker: Iſt. Wait.
sp.p: Here he comes, full daſh, and the old man trotting after him like a terrier.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Come along dad—puſh on my dear dad. —Well, here we are—keep moving.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Moving! zounds, haven't I been moving all night in the mail coach, to pleaſe you?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Mail! famous thing, isn't it? Je up! whip over counties in a hop, ſtep and jump—daſh along.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Od rot ſuch hurry ſcurry doings, I ſay. Here have I ground my old bones all night in the mail, to be eight hours before my appointment with Sir Hubert Stanley, and now I muſt ſit biting my fingers—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Biting your ſingers! no, no—I'll ſind you ſomething to do.—Come, we'll-keep moving.

div.stage: Takes his father by the arm, who reſiſits.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I beg leave—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: No proſing—To the point—

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: For ſhame—don't interrupt the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Gently, dad—daſh away, ſir.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: A ſervant of Sir Hubert Stanley has been enquiring for. Mr. Rapid.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Puſh on!

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: And expects him at the caſtle.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: That will do—puſh off—bruſh—run!

div.p: That's the thing—keep moving—I ſay, dad!

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: What do you ſay, Neddy?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Neddy! dam it, don't call me Neddy. I hate to be call'd Neddy.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Well, I won't.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: That's ſettled—I ſay—what's your buſineſs with Sir Hubert?—Some ſecret, eh?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: I won't tell you. Oh no— a bill he owes me for making his clothes and liveries.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Pugh! he's a ready-money man. I never made a bill out for him in my life—It won't do.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Well then, ſit down, and I'll tell you (they ſit). Can you ſit ſtill a moment?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: To be ſure I can—now tell me briefly—briefly.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Indeed I will not—You muſt know—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Aye—

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: You muſt know—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Zounds! you've ſaid that twice—now don't ſay it again.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Well, I won't.—You muſt know—'tis a very long ſtory.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Then I'll not trouble you.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: I thought ſo. And pray what might induce you to come with me?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Won't tell him of Jeſſy.—Oh, as we had given up trade, left off ſtitching—you know my way—I like to puſh on—change the ſcene, that's all—keep moving.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Moving! (yawns). Oh, my poor old bones! Waiter, bring me a night-gown.
sp.stage: (Waiter helps him on with a night-gown—he lays his coat on a chair).

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: What are yon at, dad?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Going to take a nap on that ſofa.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: A nap—pugh!

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Zounds! I've no comfort of my life with you.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Say no more.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: But I will, tho'—hurry, hurry—od rabbit it, I never get a dinner that's half dreſſed; and as for a comfortable ſleep, I'm ſure—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: You ſleep ſo ſlow.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Sleep ſlow! I'll ſleep as ſlow as I pleaſe; ſo at your peril diſturb me. Sleep ſlow indeed!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Now to viſit Jeſſy. Waiter!

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Sar!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: That's right—ſir—ſhort—you're a fine fellow.

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Yes, ſar.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Does Farmer Oatland live hereabouts?

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Yes, ſar.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: How far?

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Three miles.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Which way?

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Weſt.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: That will do—get me a buggy.

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Yes, ſar.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Oh, if my old dad had left off buſineſs as ſome of your flaſhy taylors to, I might have kept a curricle, and liv'd like a man. Is the buggy ready?

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: No, ſar.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: But to cut the ſhop with paltry five thouſand.—Is the buggy ready?

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: No, ſar.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Or to have daſhed to Jeſſy in a curricle. —Is the buggy ready?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p:
To have flank'd along a pair of blood things at ſixteen miles an hour. (Puts himſelf in the act of driving, and ſits on the chair where OLD RAPID left his coat—ſprings from it again) What the devil's that? Zounds! ſomething has run into my back. I'll bet a hundred 'tis a needle in Father's pocket. Confound it! what does he carry needles now ſor? (Searches the pocket.) Sure enough, here it is—one end ſtuck into a letter, and the other into my back, I believe. Curſe it! Eh! what's this? (Reads) "To Mr. Rapid—Free—
Hubert Stanley." Ha, ha, ha, here's dad's ſecret— Now for it! (Reads very quick). "Sir Hubert Stanley will expect to ſee Mr. Rapid at the Caſtle, and wou'd be glad to extend the mortgage, which is now 50,000l." What's this? (Reads again)—"Extend the mortgage, "which is now 50,000l to ſeventy." Fifty thouſand! huzza! 'tis ſo—my old dad worth fifty thouſand—perhaps ſeventy —perhaps—I'll—no—I'll—

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: The buggy's ready, ſir.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Dare to talk to me of a buggy, and I'll—

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Perhaps you wou'd prefer a chaiſe and pair?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: No, I'll have a chaiſe and twelve. Abſcond! (Exit Waiter.) I muſt—I muſt keep moving.—I muſt travel for improvement. Firſt I'll ſee the whole of my native country, its agriculture and manufactories. That, I think, will take me full four days and a half. Next I'll make the tour of Europe; which, to do properly, will I dare ſay, employ three weeks or a month. Then, returning as completely vers'd in foreign manners and languages as the beſt of them, I'll make a puſh at high life. In the firſt circles I'll keep moving. Fifty thouſand! perhaps more—perhaps—ho!

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: You can't come in.

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: I tell you I will come in.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Will come in!—that's right—puſh on, whoever you are.

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: I thought ſo. How do you do, Mr. Rapid? Don't you remember Bronze, your father's foreman, when you were a boy?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Ah, Bronze! how do you do, Bronze? Any thing to ſay, Bronze? Keep moving. Do you know, Bronze, by this letter I have diſcover'd that my father is worth—how much, think you?

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: Perhaps ten thouſand.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Puſh on.

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: Twenty.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Puſh on.

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: Thirty.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Keep moving.

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: Forty.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Fifty—perhaps—ſixty—ſeventy—oh! I;ll tell you. He has lent 50,000l. on mortgage to an old Baronet.

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: Sir Hubert St.—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I know his name as well as you do.

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: Here's news for my maſter! Well, Sir, what do you mean to do?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Do! Puſh on—become a man of faſhion, to be ſure.

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: What wou'd you ſay, if I were to get you introduced to a Nabob?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: A Nabob! Oh! ſome flaſh-in-the-pan chap.

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: Oh, no!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: What, one of your real, genuine, neat as imported, Nabobs?

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: Yes; Mr. Vortex.—Did you never hear of him.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: To be ſure I have. But will you?

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Ah! but will you do it directly?

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Then puſh off—Stop—ſtop—I beg your pardon—it cuts me to the heart to ſtop any man, becauſe I wiſh every body to keep moving. But won't dad's being a taylor, make an objection?

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: No; as you never went out with the pattern-books.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Oh yes, I did.

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: That's aukward.—But you never operated?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: What do you ſay?

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: I ſay you never—
sp.stage: (deſcribes in action the act of ſewing.)

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Oh! yes, I did.

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: That's unlucky.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Very melancholy indeed!

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: I have it. Suppoſe I ſay you are merchants.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: My dear fellow, ſink the taylor, and I'll give you a hundred.

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: Will you? Thank you.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Now puſh off.

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: But don't be out of the way.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Me! Bleſs you, I'm always in the way.

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: Don't move.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Yes, I muſt move a little—away you go— (puſhes Bronze off) . Huzza! now to awake old dad. (Exit, and returns with OLD RAPID.) Come along, dad.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Yes, ſir—yes, ſir— I'll meaſure you directly—I'll meaſure you directly.

sp.speaker: R. Rap.
sp.p: He's aſleep.—Awake!

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: What's the matter, eh? What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: What's the matter! I've found fifty thouſand in that letter?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Indeed! (opens the letter eagerly). Ah! Neddy, have you found out—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I have—that you are worth—how much?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Why, ſince what's paſt—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Never mind what's paſt.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: I've been a fortunate man. My old partner us'd to ſay, Ah! you are lucky, Rapid. Your needle always ſticks in the right place.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: No, not always (ſhrugging). But how much?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Why as it muſt out, there are fifty thouſand lent on mortgage.—Item, fifteen thouſand in the Conſols—Item—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Never mind the Items.—The total, my dear dad—the total.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: What do you think of a plum?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: A plum! Oh, ſweet, agreeable, little, ſhort word!

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Beſides ſeven hundred and ninety—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Never mind the odd money—that will do. But how came you ſo rich, dad? Dam'me, you muſt have kept moving.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Why, my father, forty years ago, left me five thouſand pounds; which, at compound intereſt, if you multiply—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: No; you have multiplied it famouſly. It's my buſineſs to reduce it (aſide). Now, my dear dad, in the firſt place never call me Neddy.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Why, what muſt I call you?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Ned—ſhort—Ned.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Ned—ſhort—Ned.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Ned! O Ned!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: That will do. And, in the next place, ſink the taylor. Whatever you do, ſink the taylor.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Sink the taylor! What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I've news for you. We are going to be introduced to Mr. Vortex, the rich Nabob.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: You don't ſay ſo! Huzza; it will be the making of us.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: To be ſure. Such faſhion! ſuch ſtile!

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Aye, and ſuch a quantity of liveries, and—Oh dear me!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: I forgot I had left off buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Buſineſs! Confound it! Now, pray keep the taylor under, will you? I'll—I'll ſend an expreſs to London (runs to the table).

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: An expreſs for what?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I don't know.—

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: The bill of fare, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Bring it here (reads). Turbots— Salmon—Soles—Haddock—Beef—Mutton— Veal—Lamb—Pork—Chickens—Ducks— Turkeys—Puddings—Pyes.—Dreſs it all— that's the ſhort way.

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: All!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Every bit.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p:
No, no, nonſenſe.—The ſhort way
indeed! Come here, ſir.—Let me ſee— (reads). "Um—Um—Ribs of beef."—That's a good thing; —I'll have that.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Ribs of beef, ſir.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Are they the ſhort ribs?

sp.speaker: Waiter
sp.p: Yes, ſir.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: That's right.

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: What liquor would your honour like?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Spruce beer.

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Very well, ſir.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I muſt have ſome clothes.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: I'm ſure that's a very good coat▪

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Waiter!—I muſt have a daſhing coat for the Nabob. Is there a raſcally taylor any where near you?

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Yes, ſir;—there are two cloſe by
sp.stage: (Father and Son look at each other)

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Umph! Then tell one of them to ſend me ſome clothes.

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Sir, he muſt take your meaſure.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: To be ſure he muſt.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Oh true! I remember the fellows do meaſure you ſomehow with long bits of—Well— ſend for the ſcoundrel.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Oh, for ſhame of yourſelf! I've no patience.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Like you the better.—Hate patience as much as you do, ha! ha!—Muſt ſwagger a little.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Ah! I am too fond of you, I am, Ned. Take my fortune; but only remember this—By the faith of a man I came by it honeſtly—and all I aſk is, that it may go as it came.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Certainly. But we muſt keep moving, you know.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Well, I don't care if I do take a bit of a walk with you.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Bit of a walk! Dam'me, we'll have a gallop together. Come along dad.—Puſh on dad.

div.head: SCENE II.—A Room in Mr.VORTEX'S Houſe.
div.stage: Enter Mr. VORTEX, ELLEN, and Miſs VORTEX.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Married to Charles Stanley! You, Madam?

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Yes, I.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: I'll not believe it.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Well, I vow that's uncommon comic. And why not, my forſaken couſin?

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Firſt, madam, I know Charles Stanley would only form ſo ſacred an alliance where his affections pointed out the object. Secondly, I feel thoſe affections to be mine.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Thirdly, an inconſtant ſwain was a thing never heard of; and, to conclude, pray peruſe that letter—

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Sir Hubert Stanley informs Mr. Vortex that his ſon embraces with eager joy the propoſals for his marriage with Mr. Vortex's daughter. (Drops the letter). Then every thing is poſſible. Oh love!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Nay, Don't you abuſe poor Cupid—his conduct has been perfectly parliamentary. Self intereſt has made the little gentleman move over to the other ſide, that's all

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Heavens! ſhould this be—

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Young Mr. Stanley, ſir.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Young Mr. Stanley, ſir.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: My ſoul ſinks within me.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Upon my honour, my dear, you had better retire.—Your agitation.—

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: I thank you, madam (going.) Hold.— No;—with your permiſſion I'll remain

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Juſt as you pleaſe. What a triumph! Oh, how uncommon delicious!

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Now heart be firm!
sp.stage: (Retires from the front of the ſtage).

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: How he's ſtruck!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Charles
sp.p: What can this mean? (aſide). Ma— mad—madam—the confuſion that—that—that—

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: I muſt cheer him with a ſmile.
sp.stage: (During this ELLEN advances to the front of the ſtage, ſo as to leave Miſs VORTEX between her and STANLEY.)

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Ah! what heaven of brightneſs breaks in upon me! Lovely Miſs Vortex, can I believe my happineſs? Will thoſe arms receive me? (Miſs VORTEX, thinking this a addreſſed to her, opens her arms; STANLEY ruſhes paſt her to ELLEN.) My Ellen!

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Oh, Charles, the ſufferings my heart underwent this moment, and the joy it now feels is ſuch, I cannot ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Nabob! Nabob!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: The matter! won't you reſent this?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Oh dear! not I.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Will you bear an inſult?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: My phyſicians order me not to mind being inſulted at all: nothing is to provoke me.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Provoke you!—If I were a man, I would—Oh!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: I don't like his looks,—he ſeems a deſperate—

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: What do you mean to do?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Why, as this is a very extraordinary caſe—

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: I think it beſt to—adjourn
sp.stage: (goes up the ſtage, Miſs VORTEX follows).

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: I perceive the miſtake; but my heart confeſs'd but one Miſs Vortex—I thought the name, like the ſuperior virtues you adorn it with, attach'd alone to Ellen. The embarraſſments of my paternal eſtate demanded a marriage with a woman of fortune.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: What do I hear?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Why this alarm?

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Alarm! Muſt not thoſe words terrify which ſeparate me from you for ever?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: What means my Ellen?

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Oh, Stanley, hear me. On my return to England, Mr. Vortex, to whom the care of my property was entruſted, was ever preſſing on my mind the difficulty of recovering my father's India poſſeſſions. Each meſſenger that arrived from you, confirmed the melancholy tale, that my Stanley was ſinking into an early grave. Oh! what then was fortune or the world to me? I ſought out ſolitude, and willingly aſſigned to Mr. Vortex what he called my expectations, for five thouſand pounds.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Yet you ſhall be mine.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: No, Charles, I will not bring you poverty. I'll return to ſolitude, and endeavour to teach this leſſon to my heart, "That it will be joy enough to know that Stanley is well and happy."

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Stay, Ellen—think deeply before you conſign the man that loves you to certain miſery.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: True—in a few hours let me ſee you again. The oppoſing agitations my mind has ſuffered unfit me for further converſation.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: In a few hours, then, you'll allow me to ſee you?

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Allow you to ſee me!—Oh! Stanley, farewell!

div.stage: Mr. and Miſs VORTEX come forward.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Now ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: We had better pair off.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: No—ſpeak with ſpirit.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: I will.—Sir, I cannot help ſaying, that every man, that is, every man of honor—

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: That's right!—ſay that again.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: That every man of honor—

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Well, ſir?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: It—is—the—the—beſt judge of his own actions.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: I perfectly agree with you—and wiſh you a good morning.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: So, then, I'm to be inſulted, deſpis'd and laugh'd at, and no duel is to take place— nobody is to be kill'd— my tender heart is to feel no ſatisfaction—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: I fight!—Do you conſider the preciouſneſs of a legiſlator's life?

div.p: "A county ſuffers when a Member bleeds."

sp.speaker: Bronze
sp.p: Oh, ſir, ſuch news!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: What, is Parliament convened?

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: No, ſir; but I have found out that the Baronet is—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: What of him?

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: Ruin'd!

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Well! that's ſome ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Bronze
sp.p: I met at the inn the Mr. Rapid's, merchants I formerly lived with, who have a large mortgage on his eſtate, and he wants to borrow more—So, ſir, I told them I was ſure my maſter would be proud to fee them at Bangalore-Hall, becauſe I thought, ſir.—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: I know—I have it. I'll ſhew them every attention; and if I can but get hold of the mortgage, I'll—

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Oh! uncommon charming!
Now do you go and write a note, and ſay we will wait on them.—Ah! uſe policy inſtead of piſtols, and I would fight any man—for, as I ſay in my ſpeech, "Policy, Mr. Speaker, is—"

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Exactly, Nabob—but I muſt write the letter, you know. Is the young merchant handſome?

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: Yes, madam.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: So much the better.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: You ſee, Bronze, the turn I give it is this—"Policy, Mr. Speaker, ſays I—"

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: Very true, ſir; but I believe my miſtreſs calls—I attend you, madam.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Confound it! Will nobody hear my ſpeech? then I'll ſpeak it to myſelf.—"Policy, Mr. Speaker—"

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: How do you do, ſur?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: What! interrupted again!—Approach, don't be afraid.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Lord, ſur, I bean't afeard; Why ſhould I;—I defies the devil and all his works.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: If this be what is called rough honeſty, give me a little ſmooth-tongu'd roguery. I don't know you, fellow!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ees, ſur, you do—I be's Frank Oatland.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Begone! I know notning of you.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ees, ſur, you do—I've a bit of a ſiſter crll'd Jeſſy.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Eh! ah!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Dom um, he knaws me well enough now.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Oh! very true—Frank Oatland, aye! Well, good Frank, how is Jeſſy?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Charming, ſur! charming!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Aye, that ſhe is, lovely and charming, indeed! (aſide)—And how are you, Frank?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I be's charming too, ſur!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: But why don't Jeſſy viſit my people here? I ſhould be always happy to ſee her.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Should you, ſur? Why, if I may be ſo bold as to ax, why, ſur?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Becauſe—becauſe—ſhe is—a—farmer Oatland's child.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: So be I, ſur. How comes it, then, that you never axes I to your balls and oſtentations? I can dance twice as long as ſiſter can.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Cunning fellow this!—I muſt buy him. Well, Frank, what are your commands?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Why, ſur, Feyther do command you to lend him three hundred pounds—no, ſur, I mean he ſupplicates.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Three hundred pounds?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p:
I'll tell you, ſur, all about it.—You knaw, ſur, Feyther have been knuckled out of a
moſt cruel ſight of money by you at weagering and cards.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: By me, fellow! Do you think I aſſociate with ſuch reptiles?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ecod, it was either you or t'other gentleman.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: T'other gentleman!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I dan't knaw which be which, not I.— There be two of you.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Two of us!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ees; there be you—that be one;—and there be your gentleman—he do make the pair.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: The pair!—And have I been buying a hundred thouſand pounds worth of reſpect for this? Have I become a Member to pair off with my valet?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ecod, and a comical pair you be!— T'other gentleman be a tightiſh, conceated ſort of a chap enough; but you be a little—he! he!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul, this is very pleaſant— You are quite free and eaſy.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Quite, ſur; quite. Feyther do tell I it be all the faſhion.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: He does!—Then you may tell Feyther, that if he has loſt his money at play, the winners won't give him ſixpence to ſave him from ſtarving, that be all the faſhion.—By their diſtreſs the pretty Jeſſy will be more in my power, and then I can reinſtate them in a farm upon terms (aſide). Go, fellow! I ſhall not ſend your Father ſixpence.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: The words I told um—the very words I told um.—Says I—"Feyther, he bean't the man will gi' thee a braſs farthing. Dong it, he hasn't it here, ſays I"

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: You ſaid ſo, did you?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ees—ſo you ſee, ſur, what a deſperate cute laid I be.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: I'll ſet a trap for you, you dog— I'll have you in my power, however; I'll drop my purſe—he'll take it—and then— (drops his purſe)— A pair of us! I'll lay you by the heels, deſperate cute as you are.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Poor Feyther, poor Siſter, and poor I! Feyther will go broken-hearted, for ſartain;—and then ſiſter Jeſſy's coming to labour.—I can't bear the thought on't. Od dom thee! if I could but get hold of ſome of thy money, I'd teak care thee ſhould not get it again.—Eh! (ſees the purſe, walks round it). Well, now, I declare that do look for all the world like a purſe. How happy it would make poor Feyther and Siſter! I conceats there wou'd be no harm juſt to touch it;— (takes it up 0 with caution;) —it be cruel tempting. Nobody do ſee I.—I wonder how it wou'd feel in my pocket (puts it with fear into his pocket). Wouns! how hot I be! Cruel warm to be ſure. Who's that? Nobody.—Oh! I—I—l-u-d, lud! and I ha' gotten ſuch a deſperate ague all of a ſudden,—and my heart do keep j—jump—jumping.—I believe I be going to die (falls into a chair). Eh!—Eh!— Mayhap it be this terrible purſe. Dom thee, come out (throws it down.—After a pauſe) Ees, now I is better.—Dear me, quite an alteration.—My head doant ſpin about ſoa, and my heart do feel as light, and do ſo keep tittuping, tittuping, I can't help crying.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Now I have him.— (Sees the purſe). What, he has not ſtole it, tho' his own Father's in want!—Here's a precious raſcal for you!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Mr. Nabob, you have left your purſe behind you (ſobbing); and you ought to be aſheamed of yourſelf, ſo you ought, to leave a purſe in a poor lad's way, who has a Feyther and a Siſter coming to ſtarving.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: My purſe! True; reach it me.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Noa, thank you for nothing.—I've had it in my hand once.—Ecod, if having other people's money do make a man ſo hot, how deſperate warm ſome folks mun be!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Warm,—fooliſh fellow! (wiping his forehead, and fanning himſelf with his hat). Fugh! quite a Bengal day, I declare.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Od dang it! how their wicked heads mun ſpin round!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Spin round! I never heard ſuch a ſimpleton.—Spin, indeed! ha! ha! God bleſs my ſoul, I'm quite giddy! Oh Lord! Oh dear me! Help! help!

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: What's the matter, ſir.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Only a little touch of my old complaint. —Send that fellow away.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Oh, this be t'other gentleman. Sur, I ha' gotten twenty-ſix pound that Feyther loſt to you at gameſtering.

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: Where is it?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: In my pocket.

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: That's lucky! give it me.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Gi' it thee! Ees, dom thee, come out, and I'll gi' it thee

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Begone!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I wiſh you both a good morning.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: What a dunderhead that is! To ſuppoſe that a little tenderneſs of conſcience wou'd make a man's head turn round.—Pugh! 'tis impoſſible;—or how the devil wou'd the Lawyers ſind their way from Weſtminſter-hall? Giddy, indeed! Ha! ha!—Bronze, take care I don't fall.

div.head: ACT III.
SCENE I.—A Room in an Inn.
div.stage: Enter OLD RAPID with a Letter, and a Servant following.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p:
What! a real letter from the real Nabob! —Dear me! where is Neddy?—Make my humble
duty to your maſter; proud to ſerve him—no—very proud to ſee him;—grateful for the honor of his cuſtom—no—no—for his company.—I wiſh you a pleaſant walk home, ſir.—The Nabob coming here directly! Oh, dear me! where's Neddy—waiter!—

div.p: Do you know where my boy is?

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Not a minute ago I ſaw him fighting in a field behind the houſe.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Fighting!—Oh, dear! where is he?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Here am I, dad.—

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: What has been the matter?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Only a ſmall rumpus;—went to peep at the caſtle,—puſhing home,—the road had a bit of a circumbendibus,—hate corners,—ſo I jumped the hedge,—cut right acroſs,—you know my way,— kept moving,—up came a farmer,—wanted to turn me back,—would not do,—tuſsled a bit,—carried my point,—came ſtrait as an arrow.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Fie, fie!—But read that letter.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: What, the Nabob coming here directly, and I in this pickle.—Waiter, are my clothes come home?

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: No, ſir.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Why, the fellow gave his word—

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Yes, ſir;—but what can you expect from a taylor?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: That's very true.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Impudent raſcal!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: What the devil ſhall I do?—the moſt important moment of my life.—

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: 'Tis unlucky.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Unlucky!—'tis perdition—annihilation —a misfortune that—

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: I can mend.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: By mending the coat.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: An excellent thought.—Come, help me off;—quick.—quick!

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: I always have a needle in my pocket.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I know you have.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Now give it me.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: What ſuffer my father to mend my coat?—No,—no;—not ſo bad as that neither.—As the coat muſt be mended,—damn it, I'll mend it.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Will you tho'?—Ecod, I ſhould like to ſee you;—here's a needle ready threaded—and a thimble;—you can't think how I ſhall like to ſee you;—now don't hurry, that's a dear boy.
sp.stage: (YOUNG RAPID ſits down, gathers his legs under him—OLD RAPID puts his ſpectacles on, and ſits cloſe to him, looking on.)

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Now mind, dad, when—Damn the needle!

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: That's becauſe you are in ſuch a hurry.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: When the Nabob comes,—ſink the taylor. —

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: I will; but that's a long ſtitch.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Be ſure you ſiak the taylor;—a great deal depends on the firſt impreſſion;—you ſhall be reading a grave book with a melancholy air.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Then I wiſh I had brought down my book of bad debts;—that would have made me melancholy enough.

div.stage: Enter Iſr. and Miſs VORTEX, who advance ſlowly, the Nabob the ſide where YOUNG RAPID is, Miſs VORTEX to the other ſide.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I,—ha! ha! I ſay, dad, if the Nabob was to ſee us now,—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Ha! ha! True;—but mind what you're about.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I'll be diſcovered in a ſituation that will ſurprize—a ſtriking ſituation, and in ſome damn'd elegant attitude

sp.speaker: O Rap.
sp.p: Why don't you ſiniſh the job?—why don't you?
sp.stage: (They look round the other way, and ſee Miſs VORTEX; they both appear aſhamed and dejected; YOUNG RAPID draws his legs from under him.).

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Gentlemen,—I and my daughter, Miſs Vortex, have done ourſelves the honour of waiting upon you, to—

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: But I beg we may not interrupt your amuſement;—'tis uncommon whimſical!

sp.speaker: Y. Rup.
sp.p: Yes, ma'm, very whimſical,—I muſt keep moving (laughs). Ha! ha! You ſee, dad, I've won,—I've won,—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: He ſays he has won—

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Oh! he has won, has he?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Yes, you know I've won; he! he! why don't you laugh?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Ha! he!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: You ſee, ma'm, the fact is,—I had torn my coat; ſo ſays I to my father, I'll bet my bays againſt your opera box that I mend it; and ſo —ha! ha! (to OLD RAPID) Laugh again.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: I can't,—indeed I can't.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: And ſo I—I won—upon my ſoul I was doing it very well.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: No, you were not,—you were doing it a ſhame to be ſeen.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Huſh!—Ah, father, you don't like to loſe.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Well, gentlemen, now this very extraordinary frolic is over—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Yes, ſir,—it is quite over,— (aſide) thank Heaven!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Suppoſe we adjourn to Bangalore-Hall?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Sir, I'll go with you directly with all the pleaſure in life

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: I believe my curriele is the firſt carriage.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Dear me!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: My daughter ſeems to pleaſe you, ſir.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: What a ſhape!

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Oh, ſir, you're uncommon polite!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: He's remarkably gallant, ma'am.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: What elegance!—what faſhion!—upon the whole, it's the beſt made little ſpencer I've ſeen for ſome time.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Oh, the devil!—The fact is, ma'am, my father is the moſt particular man on earth about dreſs —the beau of his time—Beau Rapid—You know, father, they always call'd you Bean Rapid.—I dare ſay he's had more ſuits of clothes in his houſe than any man in England.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: An uncommon expenſive whim!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I don't think his fortune has ſuffer'd by it.
Shall I have the honour of driving you?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Oh, madam, I can't think of giving you ſo much trouble as to drive me.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: My dear ſir,—I ſhall be uncommon happy!

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Oh, madam!
sp.stage: (ſimpers and titters to his ſon, then takes Miſs VORTEX'S hand, and trots off.)

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: We'll follow.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: If you pleaſe;—not that I particularly like to follow.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe, ſir, now ſummer approaches, London begins to fill for the winter.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Yes, ſir.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Any thing new in high life?—what is the preſent rage with ladies of faſhion?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Why, ſir, as to the ladies;— (aſide) What ſhall I ſay?—Oh, the ladies, ſir—why, heaven bleſs them, ſir! they—they keep moving;—but, to confeſs the truth ſir,—my faſhionable education has been very much neglected.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: That's a pity.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Very great pity, ſir.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Suppoſe I become your preceptor.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: If you wou'd be ſo kind—I wou'd treaſure any little ſhort rule.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Why there is a ſhort rule neceſſary for every man of faſhion to attend to.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Never to reflect.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Never reflect!—what puſh on—keep moving?—My dear ſir—that's my way—ſuits me exactly.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Then you muſt be known.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: To be ſure;—I'll give away thouſands in charities.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Charities!—you would be forgot in a week.—To be known, you muſt be miſchievous; —malice has a much better memory than gratitude; —and then you muſt be gallant.—Are there no pretty gills you ſhould like to be well with, eh?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: A very extenſive aſſortment, ſir.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: And perhaps there may be a married woman you would like to intrigue with.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: A very large quantity.—Oh, how I long to begin!—Are you married, ſir?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Why, no!

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: The carriage is ready.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: So am I; come, ſir,—four horſes, I hope.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: No, ſir.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: That's a great pity. Pray, ſir, will you have the goodneſs to tell your coachman to drive like the devil?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Sir, to oblige you.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Sir, I'll be very much oblig'd to you.

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Your clothes are come, ſir.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: That's lucky.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Then I'll wait for you.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Wait for me! nobody needs wait for me—I'll be with you in a crack—Do you puſh on —I'll keep moving—I'll take care nobody waits for me.

div.head: SCENE II.—A Room in the Nabob's Houſe.
div.stage: Enter OATLAND dejected, FRANK and JESSY leading him.

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Be comforted, Father,

sp.speaker: Oat.
sp.p: To ſee thee brought to ſervice! (ſighs)— I've done this:—I that ſhould have—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Never mind—we be young and healthy, and don't heed it—do us, Jeſſy?

sp.speaker: Oat.
sp.p: To be aſham'd to look my own children in the face!—I, who ought to have been the fore-horſe of the team, to be pull'd along through life by this young tender thing!

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Don't deſpond, Father—Sir Hubert will ſee your contrition, and reſtore you to his favour.

sp.speaker: Oat.
sp.p: When the hen ſees the hawk ready to pounce, ſhe gathers her young ones under her wing—when misfortune hovers over my ſweet chicken here, I leave her to ſhift for herſelf.

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Come, no more of this.

sp.speaker: Oat.
sp.p: Even the ſavage hawk takes care of its neſtlings —what then am I?—Children, do you hate me?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Hate thee! pugh, Feyther, dan't thee talk ſo—good bye to thee—cheer up—Thee has long been a Feyther to me, now its my turn, and I'll be a Feyther to thee.

sp.speaker: Oat.
sp.p: I cannot ſpeak—take care of my girl, Frank.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Care of her! though ſhe be a ſarvant, let me catch any body ſtriking her, that's all.— Well, Jeſſy, we mun not be ſheam'd—I know poverty be no ſin, becauſe parſon ſaid ſo laſt Sunday. —Talk of that—I do hear that your ſweetheart, Mr. Rapid, be worth ſuch a deſperate ſight of money as never was!

sp.speaker: Jeſſy
sp.p: If his fortunes are ſo proſperous, brother, he is exalted above my hopes—if his heart be mercenary, he is ſunk below my wiſhes— Heigh ho! yet he might have ſent to know if I were well, he might—no matter!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: He be coming to Neabob's here, on a viſitation.

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Ah! coming here!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ees—and Mr. Bronze do ſay while he be here I am to be his ſarving man.

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: You his ſervant!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Don't thee cry, Jeſſy!

sp.speaker: Jeſſy
sp.p:
I won't; it was weak, it was wrong.—Frank, be ſure you conceal
from Mr. Rapid who you are—I have reaſons for it.—Edward here!—when we meet it will be a hard trial. Yet why ſhould I dread it?—let perfidy and pride ſhrink abaſh'd, virtuous integrity will ſupport me.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: That's right, Jeſſy, ſhew a proper ſpirit —Ecod, if he were to pull out his purſe and to offer to make thee a preſent of five guineas, dan't thee take it.— (JESSY ſmiles dejectedly.)—Here be thy new miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Leave me.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Doſt thou hear? Dom it, dan't thee take it!

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Oh! my new attendant, I ſuppoſe!— What's your name, child?

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Jeſſy Oatland, Madam.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Well, Oatland, (taking out her gloſs,) look at me.—Umph—not at all contemptible.— That's a charming noſegay— (JESSY preſents it)— all exotics, I declare.

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: No, madam, neglected wild flowers—I took them from their bed of weeds, beſtowed care on their culture, and, by tranſplanting them to a more genial ſoil, they have flouriſhed with luxuriant ſtrength and beauty.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: A pretty amuſement.

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: And it ſeems, madam, to convey this leſſon —Not to deſpiſe the lowly mind, but rather with foſtering hand, to draw it from its chill obſcurity, that, like theſe humble flowers, it might grow rich in worth and native energy.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Oh! (aſide),—mind—energy!— What's the matter with the poor girl, I wonder! uncommon odd!—I hear, Oatland, you are reduced in your circumſtances.

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Yes, madam.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: That's very lucky, becauſe it will make you humble, child!—Well, and what are your qualifications?

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Cheerful induſtry, madam. I can read to you, write for you, or converſe—

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Converſe with me! I dare ſay you can.—No, thank you, child—inſtead of my liſtening to your voice, you will be polite enough to be as ſilent as convenient, and do me the honour of liſtening to mine.—Oh! here comes Mr. Rapid.

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Ah! (in great agitation); May I retire madam?

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Yes; I ſhall follow to dreſs.—No, ſtay —Yes, you may go.

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Oh, thank you! thank you, dear madam!

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: That poor girl appears to me rather crazy.

div.stage: Enter OLD and YOUNG RAPID, and VORTEX.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Welcome to Bangalore Hall, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Charming houſe! plenty of room.—

div.stage: (Runs about and looks at every thing.)

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: A very ſpacious apartment, indeed.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Yes, ſir; but I declare I forgot the dimenſions of this room.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Sir, if you pleaſe, I'll meaſure it—my cane is exactly a yard, good honeſt meaſure—'tis handy—and that mark is the half yard, and—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.stage: (Overhears, and ſnatches the cane from him.)
sp.p: Confound it! The pictures, father—look at the pictures (pointing with the cane); did you ever ſee ſuch charming—

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Do you like pictures?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Exceedingly, ma'am; but I ſhould like them a great deal better if they juſt moved a little.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Ha! ha! I muſt retire to dreſs—till dinner, gentlemen, adieu.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Zounds! you'll ruin every thing!—Can't you keep the taylor under.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Your ſon ſeems rather impatient.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Very, ſir—always was.—I remember a certain Duke—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: That's right, lay the ſeene high,—puſh the Duke—puſh him as far as he'll go.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: I will, I will. I remember a certain Duke uſed to ſay, Mr. Rapid, your ſon is as ſharp as a needle.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: At it again!

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: As a needle—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Is true to the pole, As a needle is true to the pole, ſays the Duke; ſo will your ſon, ſays the Duke, be to every thing ſpirited and faſhionable, ſays the Duke.—Am I always to be tortur'd with your infernal needles?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Now to ſound them.—I hear, gentlemen, your buſineſs in this part of the country is with Sir Hubert Stanley, reſpecting ſome money tranſactions.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: 'Tis a ſecret, ſir.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Oh! no—the Baronet avows his wiſh to ſell-his eſtate.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Oh! that alters the caſe.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: I think it would be a deſirable purchaſe for you—I ſhould be happy in ſuch neighbours— and if you ſhould want forty or fifty thouſand, ready money, I'll ſupply it with pleaſure.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, how kind!—If my ſon wiſhes to purchaſe, I would rather leave it entirely to him.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: And I would rather leave it entirely to you.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Very well, I'll propoſe for it.— (aſide). This will cut Sir Hubert to the ſoul.—There is a very deſirable borough intereſt—then you could ſit in Parliament.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I in Parliament? ha! ha!

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: No; that would be a botch.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: No, no, I was once in the gallery— cramm'd in—no moving—expected to hear the great guns—up got a little fellow, nobody knew who, gave us a three hours' ſpeech—I got dev'liſh fidgetty—the Houſe called for the queſtion, I join'd the cry—"The queſtion, the queſtion," ſays I.—A Member ſpied me—clear'd the gallery —got huſtl'd by my brother ſpectators—obliged to ſcud—Oh! it would never do for me.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: But you muſt learn patience.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Then make me a Speaker—if that wou'dn't teach me patience, nothing would.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Do you diſlike, ſir, Parliamentary eloquence?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Sir, I never heard one of your real downright parliament ſpeeches in my life—never

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: By your yawning I ſhou'd think you had heard a great many.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Oh, how lucky!—at laſt I ſhall get my dear ſpeech ſpoken.—Sir, I am a Member, and I mean to—

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Keep moving.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Why, I mean to ſpeak, I aſſure you; and—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Puſ • on, then.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: What, ſpeak my ſpeech?—That I will—I'll ſpeak it.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Oh, the devil!—Don't yawn ſo—

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: I never get a comfortable nap, never!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: You have a deviliſh good chance now— Confound all ſpeeches.—Oh!—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Pray be ſeated— (they ſit on each ſide VORTEX).—Now we'll ſuppole that the chair—

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Suppoſe it a chair! why it is a chair, an't it?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Pſhaw! I mean—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: He knows what you mean—'tis his humour.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Oh, he's witty!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Oh, remarkably brilliant indeed!—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: What, you are a wit, ſir!

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: A what? Yes, I am—I am a wit.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Well, now I'll begin.—Oh, what a delicious moment!—The Houſe when they approve cry, "Hear him! hear him!"—I only give you a hint in caſe any thing ſhould ſtrike—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Puſh on.—I can never ſtand it—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Now I ſhall charm them— (addreſſes the chair) —"Sir, Had I met your eye at an earlier hour, I ſhould not have blink'd the preſent queſtion —but having caught what has fallen from the other ſide, I ſhall ſcout the idea of going over the uſual ground."—What! no applauſe yet? (aſide —During this OLD RAPID has fallen aſleep, and YOUNG RAPID, after ſhewing great fretfulneſs and impatience, runs to the back ſcene, throws up the window and looks out)—"But I ſhall proceed, and, I truſt without interruption"—
sp.stage: (turns round and ſees OLD RAPID aſleep).

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul, this is—What do you mean, ſir?—

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: What's the matter?—Hear him! hear him!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Pray, ſir, don't bluſh— (ſees YOUNG RAPID at the window)—What the devil!—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Hear him! hear him!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: By the ſoul of Cicero, 'tis too much.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Oh, Neddy, tor ſhame of yourſelf to fall aſleep!—I mean to look out of the window —I am very ſorry, ſir, any thing ſhould go acroſs the grain.—I ſay, Ned, ſmooth him down!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I will—What the devil ſhall I ſay? —The fact is, ſir, I heard a cry of fire—upon —the—the—water, and—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Well, well—But do you wiſh to hear the end of my ſpeech?
