sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Upon my honour, I do.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Then we'll only ſuppoſe this little interruption a meſſage from the Lords, or ſomething of that ſort.—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Where did I leave off?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Oh! I recollect; at—"I therefore briefly conclude with moving an adjournment"—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Nonſenſe! no ſuch thing— (putting him down in the chair.)—Oh! I remember! "I ſhall therefore proceed, and, I truſt, without interruption.—"

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Dinner's on the table, ſir.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Get out of the room, you villain!— "Without interruption—"

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I ſay, ſir—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Hear him! hear him!

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Dinner is waiting.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap
sp.p: Dinner waiting!— Come along, ſir.

sp.speaker: Vortex
sp.p: Never mind the dinner.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: But I like it ſmoking.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: So do I—Be it ever ſo little, let me have it hot.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Won't you hear my ſpeech?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: To be ſure we will—but now to dinner. —Come, we'll move together—Capital ſpeech! —Puſh on, ſir—Come along, dad—Puſh him on, dad.

div.head: SCENE III.—An ancient Hall.
div.stage: Enter Sir HUBERT, leaning on CHARLES STANLEY.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Take comfort, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Where ſhall I find it, boy?—To live on my eſtate, is ruin—to part with it, death.—My heart is twin'd round it.—I've been the patriarch of my tribe—the ſcourge of the aggreſſor—the protector of the injur'd!—Can I forego theſe dignities? —my old grey-headed ſervants, too, whoſe only remaining hope is to lay their bones near their lov'd maſter, how ſhall I part with them?—I prate, boy, but 'tis the privilege of theſe white hairs.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Oh! ſay on, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p:
All! all is dear to me!—theſe warlike trophies of my anceſtors!—Charles, thou ſee'ſt that goodly oak, 'twas planted at my birth— Would'ſt thou think it? In the late hurricane, when the tempeſt humbled with the duſt the proudeſt of the foreſt, it bravely met the driving blaſt—my people with ſhouts of joy, hail'd the auſpicious omen, and augur'd from it proſperity to me and
mine—Fondly I believ'd it—fondly I thought it. Fie! fie! I doat—

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: My father, I doubt not but they augur'd truly. I muſt to the active world. Why ſhould I fear that the virtue and independence you have inſpir'd—

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Ah, boy! but while licentiouſneſs and party zeal command the choiceſt gifts of fortune, virtue and genius muſt be content with their leavings.

div.stage: Enter Servant—delivers a letter to Sir HUBERT, who reads it with great agitation.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Ah! what is it ſhakes you, ſir?—That letter!

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Nothing, my dear boy!—'tis infirmity! —I ſhall ſoon be better.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p:
Excuſe me, dear Sir (takes the letter and reads).
Mr. Vortex, at the requeſt of Mr. Rapid, informs Sir Hubert Stanley, it is inconvement for him to advance more money on mortgage. Mr. Vortex laments Sir Hubert's pecuniary embarraſſments—damnation!— to relieve which, he will purchaſe the caſtle and eſtate.—Sooner ſhall its maſſy ruins crumble me to duſt.—Don't deſpond, my father:—bear up!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Oh Sir!—At Neabob's table they've een ſo abuſing your father!

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Ah?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And I've been ſighting—

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Huſh!

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: What's his buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Oh, ſir! (concealing his agitation)—My friend Frank conſults me on a love aſſair; and I muſt not betray his conſidence.—In his hurry he ſell.—Wasn't it ſo

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ees, fur, ees.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: You are not hurt, young man?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: No, fur.—Thank heaven! my head be a pure hard one.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Within!— (Enter two Servants) Attend my Father.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: My boy, don't ſtay from me long.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Now, good Frank, eaſe my tortur'd mind.—What of my father?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Why, your honour, Mr. Bronze came laughing out of dining-room, and ſays, "Daame, how the old Baronet has been roaſted." So, fur, I not knowing what they could mean by roaſting a Chriſtian, axed. "Why," ſays he, grinning. "they voted, that it was a pity the dignity of the bloody hand interfer'd, or the old beggar might ſet up a ſhop."

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: The old beggar might ſet up a ſhop.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Unmanner'd, cowardly babblers.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And that you, fur, would make a dapper 'prentice.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: I heed not that.—But, when I forgive a father's wrongs—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: So ſays I, Domme, if young 'ſquire had been among them, he would have knocked all their heads together. Now wouldn't you, fur, have knock'd their heads together? Then they all laugh'd at me: which ſomehow made all the blood in my body come into my knuckles. So ſays I, "Mr. Bronze, ſuppoſe a caſe—ſuppoſe me young 'ſquire Stanley—now, ſay that again about his honour'd father."—So he did; and I lent him ſuch a drive o'the feace—and I was knocking all their heads together pretty tightiſh—till the cook laid me flat wi' the poker: then they all fell upon me; and when I could ſight no longer, I fell a crying, and run to tell your honour.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Thanks, my affectionate lad!—Return to the Nabob's to-day.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I be ſartain I ſhall never do any good there.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: To morrow you ſhall live with me. I ſhall diſmiſs all my ſervants—my circumſtances require it.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: What! all but me!—What! I do all the work?—Lord, Lord, how glad I be, fur, you can't afford to keep any body but I.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Good Frank, farewell—Hold—here

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Nay, prayee, fur, dan't you beheave unkind to me—I be a poor lad, that do worſhip and love you—not a ſpy for the lucre of gain—pray uſe me kindly, and don't gi' me a farding.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Frank, I beg your pardon—Farewell!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Lord, how glad I be he can only afford to keep I.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Inſult my father!—unmanly villain!— who'er thou art, thy life ſhall anſwer it!

div.head: ACT IV.
SCENE I.—Enter VORTEX, in great terror, reading a letter.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Dear me!—here's a terrible affair! (reads) Give me up the author of the ſlander on my father that was myſelf—I never can find in my heart to give myſelf up— or perſonally anſwer the conſequences—CHARLES STANLEY.—Oh dear! ſince I ſind my words are taken down, I muſt be more parliamentary in my language—What ſhall I do?—I can't ſight—my poor head won't bear it —it might be the death of me.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Huzza, my fine fellows! Bravo!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p:
Eh! egad, a fine thought—Young Rapid is loaded muzzel high with Champaigne— I'll tell him he ſaid the words, and make him own them. I've perſuaded him into a marriage with
my daughter; after that, the devil's in't if I can't perſuade him into a duel.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Here I am, tip-top ſpirits—ripe for any thing.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: How did you like my Champaigne?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Oh! ſuits me exactly; a man is ſuch a damn'd long while getting tipſy with other wine —Champaigne fettles the buſineſs directly—it has made me—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Lively, I ſee.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Lively—it has made me like a ſkyrocket. Well, how did I behave?—Quite eaſy, wasn't I?—Puſh'd on—at every thing—barr'd proſing.—Jolly dogs within—the fat parſon's a fine fellow—kept the bottle moving—ſaid a nice ſhort grace.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Well, and did you loſe at play the five hundred pounds I let you?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: As eaſy as could be.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: That was lucky.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Very—particularly for thoſe who won it.—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Well, now you'll do.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Huzza! I'm a finiſh'd man

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: You only want a quarrel to make you—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: A what?—A quarrel—Damme, I'll ſettle that in two minutes

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Stop.—You need not go out of the room for that.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: What! will you quarrel with me, eh? —With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Me! Oh no!—I ſay I could get you ſuch ſame—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: How, my dear fellow?—Daſh on.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Why, at dinner you reflected on the Baronet.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: No, it was you.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: No, not I.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Yes, it was you.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Well, it might be I; but I don't ſay it was—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I. do.—Puſh on.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Young Stanley has demanded the author.— Now, if you were to own the words—how the news-papers would teem with—"The elegant Charles Stanley was called out by the daſhing: Young Rapid about ſome trifle"—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Bravo!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Any thing does for a duel now a-days— the length of a dancer's great toe—an election leg of mutton and trimmings.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Say no more—I'll do it. By heavens, no man of faſhion will be more infamous—I mean more famous.—I'll go write to him directly.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Firſt take another bottle of Champaigne. You can't think what a free daſhing ſtile it will give you.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I will (going—returns.) No, I can't take up this quarrel.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Oh dear!—Why not?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Becauſe I'm ſure I'm depriving you of a pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Oh, don't mind me! I give it you, to ſhew my regard for you.—Indeed, I've had ſo much fighting in my time, that with me it really ceaſes to be a pleaſure—the ſweeteſt things will cloy—ſo the quarrel's your's—I waſh my hands of it.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: You're a damn'd good hearted, generous fellow!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Then you'll return triumphant, and marry my daughter.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: To be ſure—keep moving (going). I hope he'll fight directly.—Like a ſailor, I hate a calm, particularly when an enemy's in fight.— Hold—what muſt we ſight with? I can fence.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: You have no objection to piſtols and bullets?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I like bullets—they come ſo quick. But I muſt puſh on—the other bottle, and then— I'm a firſt-rats fellow.—Champaigne for ever!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: You ſhall have my piſtols—hey've never been uſed. (Enter Miſs VORTEX.) Here's policy. "Crown me, ſhadow me, wich laurels."—Oh my dear, I've atchiev'd two ſuch difficult points!

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: How, my dear Nabob?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: In the firſt place, I've perſuaded Young Rapid to marry you.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Was that ſo difficult?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: No, no, certainly. But the next will delight you.—Rapid is going to have an affair of honour with Young Stanley.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: A duel! and about me!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Yes.— (aſide) I may as well tell her ſo.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Charming!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Now an't I a kind father, to ſet two young men fighting about you?

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Ah! that is, indeed, acting like a parent!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Egad, I muſt look after Rapid, though.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: But how did you manage it?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: By policy, to be ſure: for, as I obſerve in my ſpeech—"Policy is—"

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: And a very good obſervation it is.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: How do you know, till you hear it?— "Policy—"

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: But pray go to Mr. Rapid

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: "Policy—"

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Nay, I muſt inſiſt— (Exit VORTEX.) Oh delightful!—Oatland!

div.p: I'm in ſuch uncommon ſpirits, Oatland!

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: May I inquire the cauſe, madam?

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Certainly. A duel is going to be fought about me.

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: A duel! Horrible thought!

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Senſibility, I now! Too comic, a vaſt deal! Ha! ha! cottage pathos muſt proceed from a ſource unknown to me, I'm ſure!

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: It proceeds, madam, from the heart.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Umph!—Let me have no more of it

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: I beg your pardon—I forgot the extent of a ſervant's duty.—I forgot that ſervants have no right to feel pleaſure or pain, but as their employers pleaſe; and that ſuppreſſing the ſenſibilities of Nature is conſider'd in their wages

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: No doubt of it.—That's ſo very ſenſibly obſerv'd, that I'll forgive you, Oatland.— The pride of young Stanley will be ſo humbled—

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Is the ſafety of that noble youth implicated?

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: What!—A lover, I ſuppoſe—came to the farm, I warrant—attended Miſs Jeſſy in the dairy—ruffled the cream with his ſighs—talked of Arcadia, and ſipped butter-milk.—Ha! ha! I ſhould not wonder, after what I have ſeen of his taſte—Yes, he is implicated—I dare ſay Mr. Rapid will—

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Heavens! Is Edward—
sp.stage: (catching hold of a chair for ſupport).

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Edward!

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: I mean, madam, (trembling and curteſying,) is Mr. Rapid's life involv'd?

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Upon my honour, you ſeem to have an uncommon ſenſibility for all mankind!—Do you mean to ſit down in my preſence?

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: No, madam! (ſinks down in the chair). Oh, Edward, unkind as thou art, how gladly would I reſign my life, to ſave thee!

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: In tears, Jeſſy?—Sweet girl, tell me—

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Oh, madam! the moſt dreadful event is about to take place. Mr. Stanley is engaged in a duel with—

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Forbid it, Heaven.—Let us fly to his Father:—he may prevent it.

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Alas, madam! I fear he regards not his Father's injunctions.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Not regard his Father:—who, child?

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Mr. Rapid, madam!

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Mr. Rapid?

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Is it ſo, ſweet Jeſſy?—But has he deſerv'd thy love?—Is he not unkind?

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Oh! true, madam!—But is not his life in danger?

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: We will not loſe a moment.—Let us ſeek Sir Hubert.

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: I'm very faint.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: I'll ſupport thee; for in addition to the oppreſſion of our common grief, thou, ſweet girl, muſt bear the agonizing weight of diſappointed love. —Come, reſt on my arm.

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Oh, ſuch kindneſs!—I cannot ſpeak— but indeed my heart feels it.

div.head: SCENE II.—Another Apartment in VORTEX's Houſe.
div.stage: Enter YOUNG RAPID, followed by FRANK, who carries Piſtols, a Sword, and Champaigne.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Got the piſtols, eh?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Here they be (lays them down).—Your Feather were axing for you, fur.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: My father!—Should any thing happen —when I reflect—Reflect—Zounds, that won't do. Some Champaigne (ſinging) "If a man can then die much bolder with brandy" (drinks). I'll write to him, however;—a few words on a ſcrap of paper may cheer him (takes a letter out of his pocket, and is about to tear a piece of it off). What! (reads) "Dear Edward, your faithful Jeſſy Oatland" (ſtrikes his head)—Jeſſy Oatland!—What a ſcoundrel I am! (kiſſes the letter).—Oh, Jeſſy, what an infernal pain at my heart!—More Champaigne!

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: A letter, ſir, from Young Stanley.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Then the die is caſt.— (Reads) "You are a ſcoundrel—meet me immediately, or,"—Um, um, a deciſive ſhort letter enough. Damn this pain.—Quick! my piſtols! Take them to Stanley Park: there wait for me.—Oh! Jeſſy!

div.stage: Enter OLD RAPID at the back ſcene.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ecod, he'll kill thee.—I'll lay half acrown 'Squire Stanley hits thee the firſt ſhot.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Piſtols—kill— Stanley!—Ned, tell me—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: My father here.—Oh, fir, nothing.—Come, drink.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Look at me.—Ah, that agitation!— Tell me the cauſe!—A parent commands you.— Your old doating father intreats it!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I muſt deceive him.—Sir, l've receiv'd an inſult that no gentleman of faſhion can ſubmit to.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Gentleman of faſhion!—Need a man reſent it?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Read that letter, and judge.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Lack a day! conſider you're only a taylor's ſon.— (Reads) "You're a ſcoundrel."— That's a hard word.—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Wou'd you have me ſubmit to be call'd ſcoundrel?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: No, I wou'dn't— (with tears). —Yes, I wou'd.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Sir, you don't feel like a man.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: I'm ſure I feel like a father!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Read on, ſir.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: "And unleſs" (wipes the tears away,) "unleſs"—I can't—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: "And unleſs you immediately give me the ſatisfaction of a gentleman, expect the chaſtiſement due to a coward."

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Chaſtiſement!—chaſtiſement!— Coward! (with irritation). We are fleſh and blood, Ned.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Wou'd you ſee me ſpurn'd?—

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.stage: (emphatically, and running into his Son's arms.)
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Pray leave me, ſir.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p:
Where ſhall I go?—What ſhall I do? —What will become of me? Oh, boy, try to
avoid it.—Remember your old father,—remember his life hangs on your's. But, Ned—don't forget you're a man!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Pray leave me, ſir.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: I will.—Farewell, my dear boy, 'twill break my old heart.—But remember you're a man, Ned.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: So, I'm proceeding full tilt to murder;—have planted a dagger in a kind father's heart—But here goes— (fills wine—throws away the bottle and glaſs)—Its power is gone. Oh— this infernal pain! Could I with honour avoid? —but (looking at the letter)—Chaſtiſement! Coward! —Damnation! I muſt puſh on. Fool! Dolt! Villain that I am!

div.head: SCENE III.—A retired place in Stanley Park.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: What can it mean?—Charles parted from me in an agony the ingenuouſneſs of his nature had not art to conceal;—he graſp'd my hand,— bade me farewell, as if it were for ever,—then broke away—leaving me a prey to wild conjecture and deſpait;—ſoon ſhall I be at peace.—infirmity, when goaded on by ſorrow, preſſes to the goal of life with double ſpeed—Surely thro' that laurel grove, I ſee two female figures glide along; my eyes are not of the beſt, and the ſorrow I have felt for my dear boy has not ſtrengthened them; —they approach—

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Pardon, Sir Hubert, this intruſion!— My name, Sir, is Ellen Vortex.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Madam, I welcome you as my daughter.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Oh, ſir!—the urgency of the moment will not allow me to thank ſuch goodneſs as I ought! —your ſon, ſir—

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Ah! What of him?

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p:
I ſaw him paſs along, he ſled from my
outſtretch'd arms,—he was deaf to my cries;—e'en now he's engaged in a duel.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Ha! (draws his ſword and is running out, ſtaggers, drops his ſword.—ELLEN and JESSY ſupport him) My functions are ſuſpended!—Oh nature! doſt thou deſert me at this moment?—Who is the villain that has cauſed it?

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Ah, my poor Edward!

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Oh that I could ruſh before my child, and receive the fatal ball in this old broken heart!— Perhaps—dreadful thought!—e'en now the deadly tube is levelled at his manly breaſt. (The report of a piſtol is heard—ELLEN ſinks into his arms.) Bear up, I cannot ſupport thee. (Another piſtol is diſcharged)—Horrible ſuſpenſe!—what a death-like ſilence!

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Death!—Oh, my ador'd Charles!

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Ah, my poor Edward!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Huzza! huzza! (enters) Huzza!—He's ſafe—he's ſafe.—

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Who?—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: 'Squire Charles,—'Squire Charles,— Huzza!

div.stage: (Exit.—Sir HUBERT folds his hands on his breaſt in ſilent gratitude.)

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Ah, my poor Edward!

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Your ſon is ſafe;—heard you the words?

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: They have ſhot life thro' me.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Jeſſy! rejoice with me— (Seeing her dejected) Wretch that I am, to forget thy ſorrows! —Take comfort, ſweet girl!—perhaps—

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Tol de rol lol—Safe and ſound—ſafe and found—tol de rol lol.—

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: My boy Neddy,—my darling Neddy, ſafe and ſound,—tol de rol lol.
sp.stage: (Sees Sir HUBERT, and bows reſpectfully. JESSY and ELLEN talk apart.)

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: So, Mr. Rapid!—How happened this, ſir?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p:
Really, Sir Hubert, I don't underſtand the cut of it; all I can ſay is, your ſon's behaviour
was—oh—ſuperſine;—when they had fired their piſtols they drew out their ſwords, and your ſon diſarm'd Neddy, and then he generouſly gave him his ſword again, which was extremely genteel,— for it was a brand new ſilver-hilted ſword, and, I ſuppoſe by the laws of honour he might have kept it.—

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Mr. Rapid, why did you break your appointment?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Mr. Vortex, ſir—

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Mr. Vortex.—I fear your ſon has ſelected an imprudent preceptor.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Choſe a bad pattern you think, ſir?— I am afraid he has—

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Will you, ſir, favour me with a few minutes converſation?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: You know, Sir Hubert, I'm your faithful ſervant to command.—
Come, let us to our hero. Will you, fair creature, condeſcend to be a crutch to an old man? (takes ELLEN'S arm.) I ſhall expect you, ſir.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Jeſſy!

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: I follow, madam. (Exeunt Sir HUBERT and ELLEN.) Do I addreſs the father of Mr. Rapid?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: You do, pretty one!

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: I beg your pardon; but are you ſure your ſon's life is ſafe —quite ſafe?—

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Yes.—A very charming girl, I declare! —I'm very much obliged to you for taking notice of my Neddy!—Poor fellow!—nobody ſeem'd to care what became of him.—I'm very much oblig'd.—A ſweet pretty-ſpoken creature as ever I ſaw! But I muſt away to the Nabob's, or I ſhall be too late for the wedding.

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Wedding! whoſe, ſir?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Whoſe! why, my boy Neddy's with Miſs Vortex, to be ſure!

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Married! Edward married! 'Tis too much—

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Eh! what! ſpeak—tell me!

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Oh, Edward! is this the return for my love? have I merited this cruel deſertion?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Deſertion!—What!—has the raſcal—I ſhall choak myſelf—Has he behaved ill to ſo ſweet a creature? Your tears tell me ſo—I'll kill him.—He's my own ſon, and I have a right to do it—Your name, your name! pretty ſoul!

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Jeſſy Oatland.—The indiſcretion of my father has made me a ſervant.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: And the diſcretion of his father has made him a gentleman—But I'll make the raſcal know you are not humbled by your Father's conduct, nor is he exalted by his, a villain!—Can he hope to be call'd a man of honour for oppoſing his head to a piſtol, while himſelf levels the ſhaft of anguiſh at an innocent woman's heart?—But I'll kill him, that's one comfort.—Come with me, ſweet one!

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Sir, I muſt attend my miſtreſs—I am ſervant to his bride—

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: I ſhall go mad!—Don't cry—If he, by marriage, won't make you my daughter— I, by adoption, will.—Good bye, ſweet Jeſſy! —Oh, the raſcal!—Cheer up?—the ſcoundrel! —Pretty creature!—The dog!—What a ſhape!—I'll kill him!

div.head: ACT V.
SCENE I.—RAPID diſcovered, and Hair-Dreſſer.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Diſpatch! why don't you diſpatch?

sp.speaker: H. D.
sp.p: Done in a moment, ſir, pray keep your head ſtill.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Oh, Jeſſy Oatland!— S'death—have not you done?

sp.speaker: H. D.
sp.p: Sit down, ſir, done in a moment.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Well, well; I'm as patient as— (Sits —Enter FRANK at the door, RAPID jumps up and runs to him). —Well!—Speak—quick!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Sur—I—that is—ſhe—no, I went—

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: You tedious blockhead—Is ſhe gone? Is Jeſſy gone?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ees, ſur.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: What! left her Father's!—Where is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I don't know—that is, I won't tell—

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: What muſt ſhe think me? What I am— a raſcal.

sp.speaker: H. D.
sp.p: Sit down, ſir;—done in a moment.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Yes, yes; I am as calm as—

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, my maſter and Miſs Vortex wait for you.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Aye, to fulfil that infernal marriage promiſe.—Oh, Jeſſy! (to FRANK) What are you at?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Sur, I were only twiddleing about my thumbs.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: You are always twiddling about your thumbs. What ſhall I do? Go to them.—No, I'll write.—I want to write.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Oh, you do?

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: I tell you I want to write.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I'm ſure I don't hinder you.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! then don't ſtand there.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: It be all the ſame to me where I ſtand—

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Thickhead, bring pen and ink.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Why did you not tell I ſo?

div.stage: Exit, and returns with pens and ink.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Oh, this infernal pain!—A candle to ſeal a letter (Exit. FRANK, and returns with a candle.) —Zounds! it is not lighted!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You didn't tell I to light it.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Was ever man plague'd with ſuch a hollow-headed ninny-hammer.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: May be that be better than a hollow-hearted one!

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Well!

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: My maſter has ſent you thoſe parchments to peruſe.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: I wouldn't read them for his eſtate.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: He will wait on you ſir, directly.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Begone all of you!—Stop (to FRANK.) Give me my coat! (FRANK helps him on with one arm.)—Bring the glaſs!— (FRANK leaves him ſo, and brings down a dreſſing glaſs.)—Leave me, dunderhead!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Bravo, my ſine fellow! you fought nobly!—I ſay, who ſir'd firſt?

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Never mind, that's paſt!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Well, now I muſt entruſt you with a little ſecret—

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: I have no objection to a little ſecret.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: In the firſt place, then, I'll read this paper.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: No; I'll read it—I ſhall read it much quicker. Reads.—"Receiv'd of Mr. Vortex the ſum of five thouſand pounds, in conſideration of which I aſſign over all my right and title to— hum, um, um—Signed, ELLEN VORTEX."— I underſtand—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Now you muſt know the father of my niece—

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Jeſſy Oatland!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: No, her name is Ellen.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: I know it, I know it—I know it—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Her father died in India.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: With all your heart!

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Zounds! keep moving, will you?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Yes, if you'll keep ſtill.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Then be quick,

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Why I am quick, an't I?—Died in India, and left her to my care. All was in—

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Confuſion.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: You are right, all was in confuſion. So I prevail'd on—

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Jeſſy Oatland!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: No, no, Ellen—to ſign that paper; ſince which, indeed her affairs have turn'd out pretty lucky. I purchas'd this eſtate with her fortune, which will be your's, my boy!—It was a very ſnug bargain.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: What a horrible thing is the gift of ſpeech!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Speech!—Did you ſay any thing about a ſpeech? Ah! had you heard mine out.—Do you remember how it began?—"Had I met your eye at an earlier hour, I ſhould"—
sp.stage: (During VORTEX's narration, RAPID, influenced by the moſt fretful impatience, has unconſciouſly bit, and torn to pieces, the paper given him by VORTEX.)

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: 'Sdeath and ſire! is this a time for ſpeeches! Is not your daughter waiting? —Is not?—Oh Jeſſy!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: True, another opportunity! But, oh! 'tis a pretty ſpeech.—Well, now give me back the paper.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: The paper!

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.p: Yes, now you have thoroughly digeſted the contents of the paper, give it me again.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Oh! the—the—the paper

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Yes; that precious ſcrap that ſecures us a hundred thouſand pounds, you dog!—Come, give it me.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: My dear fellow! you gave me no paper.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: But I did, though.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Yes, you certainly did; but then—you —you—did not—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: But I'll take my oath I did!—Come, give it me directly!—You— (ſees the fragments on the ground). Eh! what!—No;—yes.—I'm undone, I'm ruin'd.—Oh, my head! I'm going, I'm going!

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul I'm very ſorry, but—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: But what?

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: That infernal ſpeech!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Oh! (looking at the ſcraps of paper)— Eh, but hold! when he marries my daughter he'll keep the ſecret for his own ſake. Oh dear! I muſt loſe no time.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: I'm very ſorry; I'm ſure if hearing your ſpeech will be any compenſation—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: No, no, not now—come with me, all the lawyers are waiting.—Oh, pray come!

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: I'm coming, but you're always in ſuch a hurry.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: I'll ſend my daughter to him—I muſt puſh him. Pray come directly.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul you'll break your neck, if you hurry ſo. Am I always to have this infernal pain? (goes up to the glaſs). Behold a high-finiſhed raſcal at full length.—Curſe me, if I can look myſelf in the face.

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: There he ſtands!—Now, heart, be firm.—Virtuous indignation ſupport me! Sir, my miſtreſs waits for you.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Don't plague me about your miſtreſs. I'll come by and by.— (Turns round) Heaven and hell! Jeſſy Oatland!

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: My miſtreſs, ſir, waits for you.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Your miſtreſs!—A ſervant! Jeſſy Oatland a ſervant!—A ſervant to—and I—Jeſſy! my life!—my ſoul!—will you forgive—?

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Wretch!

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: I am.—I deſpiſe myſelf.—On my knees— only liſten to me.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Mr. Rapid!

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: How can you debaſe yourſelf—to—

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: How can you debaſe yourſelf—to—

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: How dare he debaſe me, madam, by offering to an honeſt heart the affections of a villain?

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Leave the room!

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Now, poor heart! having paſs'd thy pride's probation, retire to a corner, and break with weeping.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Sir! what am I to underſtand?

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: That I'm crazy.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Have I deſerv'd inſult?

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul, I don't mean to inſult you —I aſk your pardon—upon my knees

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You, fur!

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Well, I'll forgive you if you'll come directly.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: What do you want?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You be's a deſperate villain! (RAPID going to ſtrike.) Come, dan't you do that—it won't do.—Poor ſiſter! if you had drawn a harrow acroſs her heart, you could not have hurt her ſo.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Damn't—I know nothing of your ſiſter! Who the devil is your ſiſter? you—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Why! Jeſſy Oatland!

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: What! your ſiſter—the brother of Jeſſy my ſervant?—Damnation! why did not you tell me ſo? to raiſe my hand againſt the brother of Jeſſy?—I ſhall go mad!—Frank, will you forgive me? I love Jeſſy—by my ſoul I do!—And may heaven deſert me, if—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Heyday!

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Leave the room! [Exit FRANK] inſult upon inſult!—What ſatisfaction—

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: I know what you want. Come along; I'll ſight you directly.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Fight! Nonſenſe.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Then I'll aſk your pardon.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: But what the devil's the meaning of all this?

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Why, don't you ſee I'm mad?—Stark flaring mad!

sp.speaker: Stanley.
sp.p: Mr. Rapid!

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: What do you want?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Oh! Lord, how fierce Stanley looks at me. Pray come, Mr. Rapid.— (To STANLEY) Sir, your moſt obedient!

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: That little fellow will break his neck to a certainty.

sp.speaker: Stanley.
sp.p: I have juſt ſeen a lovely girl that you have wrong'd.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: I know I have; and I'll fight you again, if you like it.

sp.speaker: Stanley.
sp.p: Could the reſult beneſit Jeſſy Oatland, I would accept your invitation.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: The fact is, I am the moſt unhappy—the —What do you charge for ſhooting a man? I'll give you a thouſand to blow my brains out. I'm the moſt miſerable dog—Pray, ſir, will you tell me one thing?—Are you a man of faſhion?

sp.speaker: Stanley.
sp.p: I truſt I'm a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: That's pretty much the ſame thing—an't it, ſir?

sp.speaker: Stanley.
sp.p: It ought to be.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Pray, ſir, how did you become a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Stanley.
sp.p: Simply, by never committing an action that would not bear reflection.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Can I be a gentleman and an honeſt man?

sp.speaker: Stanley.
sp.p: Can you be a gentleman, and not an honeſt man?

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Pray, ſir, have you always an infernal pain at your heart?

sp.speaker: Stanley.
sp.p: No, ſir.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: No! Huzza! Thank you!—By heaven I'll—Now don't hurry yourſelf.—If I don't, may I—

sp.speaker: Stanley.
sp.p: Ah! Mr. Rapid, how different are our ſituations! You, poſſeſſing the love of a moſt charming and faſcinating girl, daſh the cup of happineſs away.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: May be not, my dear fellow!—Puſh on.

sp.speaker: Stanley.
sp.p: I, poſſeſſing the heart of my dear Ellen, am miſerable: becauſe on account of the narrowneſs of her fortune, ſhe compels me to abandon her.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: What! The narrowneſs of her fortune compels—

sp.speaker: Stanley.
sp.p: Yes! I ſay—

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: No! Don't ſay it again. Don't deſpair, that's all

sp.speaker: Stanley.
sp.p: She has given a fatal paper.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: A paper!—Yes, I know, I know.

sp.speaker: Stanley.
sp.p: And I'm come to take leave of her.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: No, you are not!—I'll ſhow you ſuch a ſcene.—Nay, don't aſk me any queſtions—follow me, that's all.—Wait at the door; and when I cry, Hem! come in. But don't be in ſuch a hurry. By heavens, the pain in my ſide is better already! Huzza!—Come along! (Going, returns, and runs to the glaſs and nods.) How do you do? How do you do? What! you raſcal! you can grin again, can you? Come along; but don't hurry; becauſe, my dear fellow! 'tis impoſſible to do any thing well in a hurry. Come along! but, zounds! never hurry.

div.head: SCENE II.—Another Apartment in VORTEX's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: How bee'ſt thee now, Jeſſy?

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Better. Quite recover'd. What paſs'd between you and Edward?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Why, at firſt, he were in a deſperate paſſion; but when I told him I were thy brother, he were ſo humble, and did ax I; ſo to forgive un, that I could ſay no more to un. Dom it, I could not hit him, when he were down; and I've a notion his conſcience was pegging him about pretty tightiſh. He ſwear'd he did love thee!

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Did he, Frank? Did he ſay he lov'd me?

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: What! torn the paper!—A hot headed—only wait till he's my huſband—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Egad, I wiſh he would come, tho'—

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Oh! here he is.

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: How my poor frame trembles!

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: I vow I feel uncommon diſcompos'd —Oatland! your arm, child!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Heavens, how intereſting! the languor of thoſe lovely eyes—

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Flattering creature!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: My ſenſes are reſtor'd. Oh, will you pardon—will you again receive a heart full of love and adoration?—

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: What ſhall I do?—I muſt pardon him.

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Edward! what ſhall I ſay?—your love has been too long my joy,—my pride, to be torn from my heart without many a bitter wound;— (Miſs VORTEX with ſurprize and chagrin withdraws her arm from JESSY;)— but your late conduct has been—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Deteſtable?—But I'm pardon'd, your eyes tell me ſo. Thanks, my angel! (running to her and kneeling.) I'm ſo oppreſs'd with joy.— Ma'am, will you have the goodneſs to help me up?—

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Help you up!—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: He! he! he! Gi' me a buſs, Jeſſy! he! he! thee be's a domn'd honeſt fellow! (ſhaking RAPID's hand.) I'll run and tell poor Feyther —Now I ſhall have a farm of my own! (capering and ſnapping his ſingers.)—Dong it, how I will work. He! he! he!

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: To be us'd ſo twice in one day!—it is not to be borne.—Nabob! won't you ſight him?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: No, not I.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: Coward!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: You'd better be quiet, or I'll convince you I'm none, however.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: He! he! I declare it is ſo uncommon ridiculous!—ſo comic!—He! he!—I'm quite faint with laughing.

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Shall I aſſiſt you?

sp.speaker: Miſs Vor.
sp.p: No! (reſentſully.) I muſt retire, or I ſhall expire with laughing!—he! he!—Oh!—

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Heaven! what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Allow me to introduce Mrs. Rapid, madam.—

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Sweet Jeſſy!—Sir, I thank you, for giving my heart a pleaſurable ſenſation which I thought it had for ever taken leave of.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Bleſs your heart! perhaps I may tickle it up a little more.— (To VORTEX) Now, ſtand out of the way, will you?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: You're quite free and eaſy.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: My way.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: You forget 'tis my houſe.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: No, I don't;—you bought it with her money, you know—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Umh!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Mum, now for young Stanley's cue. (To ELLEN) 'Ppon my honour, ma'am, any man might be proud to—Hem—He doesn't hear me— Such beauty!—ſuch a ſhape! ſuch a—Hem—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Zounds! he's here again (getting behind YOUNG RAPID). What does he want?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Shall I aſk him?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Do.—I'll be very much oblig'd to you.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I will.—I'll manage

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Oh, thank you!

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Once more, my Ellen! ſupported by indulgent parent's bleſſing on our union, I entreat—

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Oh Charles! ſhall I then return your father's goodneſs by deſtroying his hopes for ever? Shall I repay my Stanley's love by inſlicting on him penury and ſorrow? In pity, no more!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.—
sp.p: What may may be your buſineſs here, ſir?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: I came to take leave.—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Huſh! (apart).—To inquire reſpecting that lady's fortune. We'll ſoon anſwer all that, won't we?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: I ſay, ſir—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: We grant it,—we grant Mr. Vortex has recover'd property to a conſiderable amount, but what ſigniſies that? She aſſigned it for five thouſand pounds!—You ſee how I'm going on

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Oh, thank you, my dear friend!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I've ſeen the paper; haven't I?—

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: And I ſhou'd be ſatisfied—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: You wou'd be ſatisfied if you faw. it— Certainly—very proper—nothing in nature can be more reaſonable; ſo, Nabob, ſhew him the paper, and ſettle the buſineſs at once (walks about, VORTEX following him.). Shew him the paper!—don't keep the gentleman waiting all day.—Shew him the paper. My dear fellow! what's the uſe of walking after me? Shew him the paper.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.stage: (taking advantage of the pauſes in the foregoing ſpeech.)
sp.p: I ſay, my dear friend, huſh! Be quiet! I want to ſpeak to you; you forget you deſtroyed it.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I deſtroyed it!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Huſh!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: He ſays I deſtroyed it!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: I did not.—I'll take my oath I did not.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: And it is true.

sp.speaker: Charles and Ellen.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: True, upon my honour! He has no more hold on your eſtates, madam, than I have.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Will you now allow the humble Stanley to deſtroy the hopes of wealthy Ellen? Will you permit me to repay your love with penury and ſorrow?

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Oh, chide on! (raiſing him) Dear Stanley, my happineſs is now complete.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p:
This is your houſe, ma'am. I give
you joy!—Sir, I give you joy!—Nabob, I give you joy!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Oh, my head! You villain!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Don't talk about villainy,—it will make you worſe. Sit down, my dear fellow!

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: He's juſtly puniſhed for the falſehood of the ſtory he told.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I ſay, he's juſtly puniſhed for the length of the ſtory he told.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Mr. Rapid, in expreſſing my obligations, allow me to be—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Not more than a minute, I entreat.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Be patient.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: I won't.—Let me come at him.

div.stage: Enter OLD RAPID and SIR HUBERT.

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: Your bleſſing, ſir!

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: What? Oh!
sp.stage: (falls down on his knees and embraces them both.)

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Mr. Rapid, by aſſerting your character as a man of honour, in rewarding the affections of this amiable woman, you command my praiſe; for beſtowing happineſs on my dear Charles, receive an old man's bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Approbation from Sir Hubert Stanley is praiſe indeed.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Dam'me, there's the ſon of a taylor for you!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: What, a taylor?

sp.speaker: O. Rat.
sp.p: Yes; and let me tell you, that one guinea honeſtly gotten by blood drawn from the ſinger, is ſweeter than a million obtained by blood drawn from the heart!—So, take that.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Well, Nabob, how do you feel?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p:
Egad, 'tis very odd;—but I declare I feel light and comfortable ſince Ellen has got her
eſtate, and I ſomehow breathe more free. I've a notion the laſt line of my ſpeech is true.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Come, I'll hear the laſt line.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Why, that the firſt ſtep towards ſecuring the eſteem of others, is to ſecure your own.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Stick to the laſt line.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: And, dear uncle, take Sir Hubert Stanley for your phyſician. Follow his preſcription of juſtice and benevolence, and my life on it, you will ſoon thank me for my recommendation.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Well, to ſhew the ſincerity of my intentions, allow, me, Ellen, to preſent you theſe parchments, the title deeds of this eſtate.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: I ſay, Ned, what nice meaſures they would make!

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: And, ſir, allow me to ſhew you the true value of riches— (giving parchments. to STANLEY)— Convert them into happineſs.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Well, I've only one obſervation to make.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I hope it is a ſnort one.

sp.speaker: Jeſſy.
sp.p: What, impatient again?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I am; and if I err

q.l: 'Tis you, my gen'rous Patrons, are the cauſe,
My heart's impatient for your kind applauſe.

div.head: EPILOGUE,
div.byline: WRITTEN BY M. P. ANDREWS, ESQ. M. P. SPOKEN BY MRS. MATTOCKS.

lg.l: SHAKESPEARE, a ſhrewd old quiz, in his dull age,
Said, very gravely, "All the world's a ſtage."
But if the Poet on our times could drop,
He'd rather own that "all the world's a ſhop."
"And what's the trade?" exclaim the critic railers
Why, "Men and women all are merely taylors."
Nay, frown not, Beaux; and Ladies, do not pout
You've all your cuttings in and cuttings out.
And, firſt, Miſs Hoyden, juſt eſcap'd from ſchool
Slighting mamma, and all domeſtic rule;
If ſhe on faſhion's road ſhould chance to trip,
What ſays the world? why, "Miſs has made a ſlip.
And if, a falling character to ſave,
She weds with age juſt tott'ring o'er the grave,
The ſportive world will ſtill enjoy the joke,
And ſpouſe, at home, at once is made a cloke.
The Politician too, who when in place,
Views public meaſures with a ſmiling ſace,
Croaks, when he's out, a diſcontented note,—
Sure he's a taylor—he has turn'd his coat.
Oft have I meaſur'd you when cloſely ſitting,
To ſee what twiſt, what ſhape, what air was ſitting.
Once more I'll try, if you'll make no reſiſtance;
Mine's a quick eye, and meaſures at a diſtance.
Great Mr. Alderman—your worſhip—ſir,
If you can ſtomach it, you need not ſtir,
Room you require, for turtle and for haunch,
'Tis done—two yards three quartersround the paunch.
Slim ſir, hold up your arm—Oh, you're a Poet,
You want a coat, indeed—your elbows ſhow it.
Don't tremble, man; there's now no cauſe for fears,
Though oft you ſhirk the Gemmen of the ſheers;
Genius ſtands ſtill, when taylors interpoſe,
'Tis like a watch—it ticks—and then it goes.
The needle dropt, the warlike ſword I draw,
or oft our ſex muſt yield to martial law;
ady Hubbuffet came to me laſt night,
"Oh, my dear ma'am, I'm in ſuch a fright:
"They've drawn me for a man; and, what is worſe,
"I am to ſoldier it, and mount a horſe:
"Muſt wear the breeches." Says I, "Don't deplore
"What in your huſband's life you always wore;
"But that your La'ſhip's heart may ceaſe from throbbing,
"Let your fat Coachman mount upon fat Dobbin;
"And for the good old pair I'll boldly ſay,
"Nor man, nor horſe, will ever run away."
"Run!"—"Arrah, who is that dare fear betray?"
Cries patriot Paddy, hot from Bantry-Bay.)
"The Frenchmen came expecting us to meet 'em,
"And ſure we all were ready there to greet 'em,
"With piping hot potatoes made of lead,
"And powder that would ſerve inſtead of bread;
"And, by my ſoul, ſuch dainty fine fat frogs,
"With warm dry lodging for them in the bogs."
"They came, alas!" cried I, of terror full.
"They made a conqueſt?"—"No, they made a bull."
But ſoftly—what with meaſures, bulls, and battle,
You muſt be tir'd with my poor fooliſh prattle;
But while you look ſo plea • ant, kind and elever,
Had I my way, I'd talk to you for ever.
